Recognizing the pressing issues of violent crime, including knife crime and violence against women, Paul vows to prioritize these critical areas, ensuring that our streets are safe for all residents. Drawing on years of experience and a deep understanding of local dynamics, Paul will work tirelessly to implement targeted strategies to address these specific challenges head-on.

But the Liberal Democrats knows that true progress requires more than just reactive measures. With a focus on prevention, Paul aims to reduce crime at its roots, investing in community initiatives, youth programs, and early intervention strategies. By addressing the underlying factors that contribute to criminal behavior, Paul is committed to creating lasting change and building a safer, more prosperous future for Cheshire.

Central to Paul's platform is the implementation of restorative justice practices, offering a compassionate and effective alternative to traditional punitive measures. By fostering accountability, healing, and reconciliation, restorative justice not only reduces reoffending but also strengthens community bonds, promoting a sense of trust and cooperation between law enforcement and the public.

With deep roots in the community, Paul brings a wealth of experience to the table. Married and parent of two, Paul understands the importance of building a secure environment for families to thrive. Moreover, Paul's tenure as a town councillor reflects a proven dedication to public service and a keen understanding of local governance.

As the Cheshire Police and Crime Commissioner election approaches, The Liberal Democrats Paul Duffy, stands ready to lead with integrity, compassion, and a bold vision for a safer, more just Cheshire.

I come from Warwickshire but have lived in Cheshire East for more than 10 years. I went to University in Aberystwyth and then Glasgow, studying Maths, Energy and the Environment. Afterwards, I worked as an environmental volunteer, and then for five years with a charity, training people to carry out home energy audits and promoting energy efficiency for affordable warmth. After that, I met my wife, became a teacher, moved to Dumbarton, got married, became a father, moved again to follow my wife’s career to Alsager, with a four-year spell in Congleton. Now, having left teaching, and having experienced a period of foster caring, I am in the enviable position of being a house-husband.

Our society is not fair. In the last ten years, the government has removed vast swathes of our social estate; the backbone of life in Britain which is there to support us all - rich or poor - in small or large amounts, depending on our need and at different stages in our lives. We must replace that with a proper end to austerity – not just for an election year. We need more resources for education; for mental health; for an NHS with fewer pills and quick fixes, and more physiotherapists and osteopaths; for a law system which can properly represent those of us without a six-figure bank balance; for libraries and public spaces; for the police; and for services for the elderly that allow them to continue to live in their own home, a protected home, or in a home specifically tailored toward their needs.

We also need to stop the constant privatisation of our country. This privatisation has “given us” much lower levels of effective service, made us poorer, and unsure about our jobs and our lives, prevented us from knowing who we need to contact about fixing or improving things, and has made huge profits for a very few.

Britain is hugely responsible for climate change. Historically, we have emitted more CO2 per person over the last 200 years than any other nation in the world. Most of that carbon is still there, creating havoc with the world’s climate. So now we should lead the way in demonstrating that we can live in a carbon-free society where we derive all our energy from renewable sources. This will require us to change our habits as well as prioritise the use of our limited resources – like steel, concrete, and rare earth metals which will needed to build renewable energy systems.

The Green Party way is fairer and more democratic – to encourage us all to take part by having a more representative voting system, with more decisions taken locally and fewer decisions overridden by government ministers. It is to encourage people to make the right decisions through sensible and realistic uses of taxation. It is to make us a society with the time and the resources to care about our neighbours and communities rather than only being able to focus on family and friends.

I am proud to have spent more than 30 years representing working people.



My dad was a bootmaker in Raunds and I am a Northants lad, born and bread. I started my working life as a postal worker with Royal Mail and became a trade union rep' speaking up for postal workers across Corby & East Northants.



We have a chance for change and I want to lead that change as your next Member of Parliament. I want to earn your trust and restore your faith in politicians

Chris moved to Northamptonshire in 1996 with his wife Linda and their two daughters. He was employed by South Northamptonshire Council as Deputy Chief Executive before retiring in 2010. Public Service has been a consistent theme in Chris's life having worked for over 30 years in local government. During that time Chris has worked on projects with both local and central government departments. Preserving and improving the environment is a key interest reflecting Chris's formal training as an Environmental Health Officer. ​ Since being elected as a district and county councillor Chris has supported local communities by making sure they have a strong voice. He has led various campaigns and has successfully fought to ensure that local priorities are recognised by decision makers. As a councillor Chris has built up strong connections with various local groups advising and supporting them when required. ​ Volunteering as a school governor, charity trustee and an active gardener with the National Trust keeps Chris in touch with local people and exposes him to a broad range of views and opinions.

Coventry is the city where I was born and grew up. I went to Bishop Ullathorne school and got my first job at British Home Stores. Having served as the Labour MP for Wakefield, as a government minister, and in the Shadow Cabinet, I want to use my experience to make a difference in my home city. Coventry has been rocked by 14 years of Tory chaos which have stretched our public services to breaking point. People are struggling to pay their bills and feed their families. In some parts of our city, 40% of children live in poverty. We need schools that give every child the best start in life, more police to tackle the fly tippers and car racers and more nurses and doctors to reduce NHS waiting lists. We must attract new green jobs to our city, insulate homes , cut air pollution and end homelessness. We need a fairer tax system and an economy that works for working people. It would be an honour to represent my home city in Parliament. If you live in Coventry East and have any questions or just want to say hello, please get in touch!

Stephen Gray is standing again as the Green Party candidate for the Holbrook ward in this year’s election. He stood as the Green Party candidate for Holbrook in the 2021 local election. He received 1,419 votes and came 2nd, just short of winning by 326 votes!

“I have lived in Coventry since 1996, joined the Green Party in 2008, and have been involved in a wide variety of community activities, from debt counselling to Coventry Motofest. I am particularly keen to improve road safety, deal with litter and flytipping, and ensure that we build new housing on brownfield sites before we even consider building on our Greenbelt.”

As a father of two and entrepreneur who believes in aspiration and hard work, I want to use my experience to tackle the problems facing Coventry and our country. 

After running my own business for 18 years, I have the real world skills to make Coventry an even better place to live, work and raise a family.

Since December 2019, I have had the honour of serving as the Member of Parliament for Coventry North West. Every day I work hard to make sure that Coventry is the best place to grow up in and the best place to grow old in.

Coventry is my home. The issues that affect you, also affect me and my family. As your Labour MP, I will always stand up for you -- so please don't hesitate to get in touch if you require my support.

I hold regular advice surgeries every Thursday, along with my monthly community coffee afternoon.

If you would like to book one of our 30-minute appointments, please email taiwo.owatemi.mp@parliament.uk or call 024 7767 2089. As usual, please remember to include your name, address and telephone number, along with a brief outline of the issue.

Esther Reeves is standing as the Green Party candidate for the Holbrook ward in this 2023 local election. Esther stood as the Green Party candidate for the Lower Stoke ward in the 2022 local election and received 400 votes. Esther says: "I came here to Coventry for Uni and never left. I've helped set up and run many community projects including Freegle and Five Acre Community Farm. For me the Green Party is the obvious party, because it combines concern for the wider planet with strong social justice policies and both the environment and people are important to me. Alongside Councillor Stephen Gray, I enjoy engaging with people in Holbrooks hearing their concerns and where possible helping with them. I believe passionately we can do more as a community than as individuals, so we need to work together to make our city a better place."

Anne Patterson is standing again as the Green Party candidate for the Whoberley ward. Anne stood for the Green Party in this ward in the 2023 local election achieving 3rd place with 378 votes.

"I have lived in the Whoberley area of Coventry since moving here over thirty years ago to study Occupational Therapy at Coventry University.  I now work as a Team Manager for Memory Assessment and Community Dementia Services in Coventry so I am very well aware of the challenges facing the NHS and Social care.  I joined the Green Party as it is the only party that truly represents my aspirations for a sustainable and just society for our planet and its people.  I am actively involved in campaigning for local action to reduce carbon emissions and protect our precious green spaces.  I believe having a stronger Green presence on Coventry City Council will help change things for the better in our city."

It's a huge honour to be the Member of Parliament for Coventry South.

Since I was elected in December 2019, I have been working non-stop for Coventry South: Supporting 10,000s of local people with casework, volunteering with Coventry charities, and winning campaigns like getting free parking reinstated for local NHS staff.

I have put my principles into practice: From raising £12,000 for Coventry Foodbank, to rejecting the £2,200 MPs' pay rise and donating it to local charities instead.

In Parliament, I hold the Conservative government to account, championing calls for proper pay rises for workers, cuts to energy bills, and fair taxes on the super-rich.

I'm Calum from Kirkcaldy, I'm a freelancer in the film industry and an volunteer for 2 educational charities. I want to get into government to leave you alone. If elected I'd so what's possible to stop the government going out of control with our civil liberties. I'm also not entirely convinced that our government is as efficient with our money as it should be, and that too many resources are being diverted to unimportant yet fashionable issues. I'd do what I can to keep our government humble, and accountable.

It has been an absolute privilege to have been your local Councillor since September  Ali, Helen & I have been hard at work across Castle Ward - but there’s still so much more we want to achieve. We know how disappointed local residents have been at the length of time it takes even just the smallest tasks with bushes left untrimmed, potholes unfilled and litter left all across our area. Like many residents, I really do question if we get our money’s worth. In spite of all this, I’m determined to keep fighting for all residents to make sure your voice is heard loud and clear. Please vote for me on May 5th so I can keep working hard for you. Thank you, Cllr Thom Campion

Emma is the Labour and Co-operative Candidate for the newly created Cramlington and Killingworth seat at the next election. She was born and brought up here, and started out working for North East Ambulance Service as a 999 Call Handler.



Since 2011 Emma has worked on various campaigns focused on improving the lives of working people. After a lack of local employment opportunities, Emma moved to the Midlands where she worked with the police and was responsible for overseeing services for survivors of domestic abuse and sexual violence, as well as volunteering as a Magistrate and a Vaccinator during the pandemic.



Moving back home after Covid, Emma now lives locally and is a First Responder with the ambulance service, as well as a school governor for a local Primary School. After 14 years of Conservative government, she is determined to ensure a fresh start for every one of our towns, villages and settlements.

The current first-past-the post , two party system, can be seen to have ground to a halt and we are seeing a vast range of negative consequences from this lack of meaningful democracy.

 

Real positive and lasting change will not be achieved by Parties who keep doing the same thing endlessly to appease the interests of those who currently benefit most from the inaction we see on the climate catastrophe and rising inequality.

 

Only the Green Party are actively campaigning for policies that will address the root causes of the ills that currently sweep our nation and stand up for those who most need an active voice working for their interests, and not those of the major polluters or media moguls who sow discord amongst society to further their own financial interests – who are currently very well represented in Westminster.

 

I shall be an active voice campaigning for changes to the voting system to ensure people’s votes truly count; for policies that protect our environment to allow us to live healthier lives and to secure the future for those who shall inherit our world after we have had our time as custodians; to work to reduce inequality and to ensure those with the broadest shoulders bear more of the weight for the changes we and our planet need.

 

I have worked as a Social Worker for over a decade and previously volunteered with a number of charities, as well as working as a delivery driver, Door Supervisor and postman. I am proud  of my working class background, as well as being the first person in my family to attend University and enter a professional role. In my professional life I have supported a vast number of people with a considerable range of challenges, from homelessness to addiction to accessing services that had previously excluded them. I have a lived experience of working endless hours for little reward and the challenges this can bring. I feel given my experience and advocacy skills, I will be able to ensure that I can act to address the individual issues faced by constituents in Killingworth and Cramlington, as well as making sure the area’s broader needs are heard within Parliament.

I would be proud to represent Killingworth and Cramlington, an area I worked within for many years. We deserve a party and candidate that will act in everyone’s interests and not those of billionaires or the old Parties that have taken us for granted for decades.

Zack Ali got married in 2009 and made Crawley his home. Since then, he has been a resident of Broadfield. Zack is a proud father of two young boys, both of whom went to Hilltop Primary School in Southgate.  He has received an honours degree in Business management and finance from University of Surrey.

In 2007 he worked for Domino’s Pizza and quickly ended up managing several stores across Sussex and Surrey. He was based at the store on Crawley High Street and led a team of store managers from across the region and was responsible for more than 200 staff. The Crawley store became one of the top 10 performing stores worldwide, whilst under Zack’s leadership. He went on to start his own business, this grew it to the point where it employed over 50 people and served thousands of customers every year.

Zack was elected to Crawley Borough Council and West Sussex County Council in 2021, representing Southgate and Gossops Green division of Crawley. He has sat on several committees and is a member of the shadow cabinet for Planning and Economic development on Crawley Borough Council.

He has been actively involved in Crawley politics since 2007, having worked alongside Henry Smith MP on various local issues and campaigns. Zack has also played a key role in several general election campaigns supporting Henry Smith MP to win the Crawley seat.

He has worked with a number local and national charities in support of a range charitable causes and issues. Including during the pandemic, where he gathered several likeminded people to set up a group to support vulnerable local residents. This group did grocery and food shopping for shielding families, vulnerable households and those on low incomes.

Zack also joined the NHS Volunteer Responders and helped local communities across Crawley to stay safe and feel supported. Taking part in activities such as welfare phone calls with residents living alone and dropping of medication and care packages.

Iain Dickson (Gossops Green) is a long serving member of the Green Party and an even longer serving member of the Crawley community. Iain is also the Green Party prospective parliamentary candidate for Crawley and stood in the 2019 General election gaining Crawley Green Party’s best ever result!

Crawley is my home. I was born here, went to school here, and I am now raising my own family in the town.

For 14 years, I have served Crawley as a borough councillor. During my eight years as council leader, I delivered balanced budgets without making front line cuts, oversaw Crawley’s return to council house building on a scale not seen for decades, and helped to secure hundreds of millions of pounds of investment in the town which saw Crawley become the densest centre of employment in the country outside of London.

I am running in this election because, after years of struggle on the ground, I know that the challenges facing Crawley on the ground cannot be resolved at the local level any longer, they need a change in Government. We urgently need a solution to our cost of living crisis, to Crawley’s housing emergency, and the underinvestment in our public sector which has left every service from the NHS to policing on the brink of collapse.

If elected, I will spend the next five years of the next Parliament working to secure:

1) A thriving local economy and support for the town centre 2) Housing which delivers for local people 3) A better future for Crawley’s children 4) Real action on crime and antisocial behaviour 5) A better-resourced NHS that’s there when you need it

Together, I know we can win. Together, I know we can build a better future for Crawley.

With best wishes,

Peter

Connor and his young family live in Crewe and Nantwich. Connor works in the constituency in Police complaints. His wife works at a local primary school. His daughter was born at Leighton hospital.

Connor is dedicated to his community. During the Covid-19 pandemic he volunteered delivering prescriptions and food to vulnerable residents. He has served as a school governor at a thriving community nursery school in Crewe. As a local councillor, Connor works day in, day out to improve the community for residents in the Crewe West ward.

In his professional life, Connor works to drive standards and public confidence in policing. Connor is committed to restoring trust and integrity in politics and our institutions.

Connor is committed to representing all of Crewe and Nantwich because it is his home. It is his community. He will work tirelessly to get a better deal for Crewe and Nantwich, befitting of the proud heritage of each town, village and parish while boldly looking to a new, brighter future for our residents and our communities.

party_name: The Official Monster Raving Loony Party

statement_to_voters:
“I am really pleased to be selected to stand for the Green Party in Croydon South, to offer people realistic hope for the future.

Over recent years we’ve seen our country run into the ground - bills rising, businesses failing, and underfunded public services falling apart when we need them most.

As the COVID enquiry progresses we can see how the Conservative Government failed us when we needed them to be dealing with the pandemic. Sadly they are also completely failing us as we face the climate and ecological emergency that threatens the future of humanity.

But just getting the Conservatives out isn’t enough. The other parties are only offering tinkering around the edges, not real solutions to the problems we face.

That’s why I’m so proud of our Green New Deal policies. We are putting forward plans that not only tackle the climate emergency, they support small businesses, bring public services back into public hands, put money back into the local economy and back into people’s pockets. Our Green New Deal would make us a world leader in delivering a sustainable economy, an example to others and a country to be proud of.

We deserve better than the Government we have had, and we deserve better than the no-change options offered by the other opposition parties. If you want better, it’s time to vote for it. This time, vote Green.”

About Elaine

Elaine was brought up in in Croydon and has lived here most of her life.

Elaine has worked in both public and private sector during her career and she has run her own business. She currently works for an advisory and financial services firm that is focussed on helping business and capital accelerate the transition to net zero.

Elaine has taken part in a variety of voluntary community work including helping long-term unemployed people with their CVs and job interview techniques; helping women new to this country to learn English; and working with a national charity tutoring disadvantaged GSCE pupils.

In Croydon Elaine has been involved in a number of projects to improve our environment. She led work setting up the ‘Bee World’ garden at Heathfield House and recently helped fundraise for the Trees4Croydon scheme to get more trees planted in our streets and green spaces.

Benjamin Justin Lewis Taylor (or Ben) co-founded Croydon Mutual Aid, he sits on the Youth Crime Board for Croydon and is passionate about bringing communities together and ensuring that they are involved in the decision making process that dictates what happens in their local area.

He has two priorities, clean streets and safe streets and will work to deliver on those items.

Simon is a retailer by profession and has lived in Croydon since 2019. Waddon residents have been ignored for too long and Simon is passionate about making their voices heard and making sure results are delivered. Simon is determined to work hard for all Waddon residents, tackle anti social behaviour and deliver sensible planning. Waddon is a special place in Croydon and deserves a council that works for them!

Sarah Jones has been the MP for Croydon Central since 2017. Before entering Parliament she had a long career in the public, private and voluntary sector. As a senior civil servant, she was part of the winning team that delivered the London Olypmics in 2012.



Sarah set up the All Party Parliamentary Group on knfe crime and sucessfully campaigned for a range of policy changes and funding to tackle the causes of knife crime.



She is a lifelong Croydon resident and proud to stand up for her hometown in parliament, while also helping residents with whatever issues they may be facing.



She has been the Shadow Minister for Industry and Decarbonisation since 2023, previously serving as the Shadow Minister for Policing.

Kim Arrowsmith is a Dagenham headteacher, who has taught in Barking and Dagenham for 7 years.

Kim is very concerned about the chronic underfunding of our public services by the current Tory Government, and particularly the impact this is having on the ability of our schools and hospitals to deliver for the local community.

Kim knows that the cost of living crisis has hit Dagenham residents hard and believes the Council should be doing more to support people. He also believes in protecting our vital green spaces from the threat of over development.

Born and raised in a Dagenham council house, I was educated locally, and I have worked my entire life in Dagenham & Rainham. I was proud to be selected to stand for Labour here. There is no community I would rather represent.



I have managed the office of Jon Cruddas MP for fourteen years and his support means everything to me. Prior to this job I worked in insurance, in a call centre, and was also a barmaid at the Dagenham Trades Hall. I understand just how precarious work can be for people in areas like ours. That is why I am an active trade unionist and proud to be backed by giants of the labour movement.



Dagenham & Rainham has a proud heritage, and it is important to me that we maintain a strong identity. I am fiercely proud of our area and will always lead from the front. Many of you already know me as someone who gets things done.



As your Prospective Labour Candidate, should I make it to Parliament, I will continue to champion council housing as I have always done, hold the police to account to help tackle crime in the area, and offer a new model of politics which puts our community at the heart of my vision for the future.



The cost of living, decent jobs and pay, housing, and public services. The next election will be about living standards, security, and opportunity. I want all of you to have a voice. Together we can build the Dagenham & Rainham of the future.

Living and working in the North East for my whole life, I am a passionate northerner, proud of our rich heritage and the bright future we have, but I have often felt that the north could be better represented than it has been in the past. Living locally, and building a business in the Tees Valley and North Yorkshire, I want to be an MP who stands up for our town and will be an ambassador for it.

I have worked hard for a variety of charitable causes alongside building my business over the past decade. The energy I have put into everything I have done in my life so far, I now want to put to good use for this great town. I will be a visible campaigner on local issues and work hand in hand with the great Conservative team of Councillors locally and our fantastic mayor Ben Houchen.

Darlington and the surrounding area is a great place that has so much going for it. But it has been let down for decades because the Labour party regard it as a “safe” seat. I am appalled at the way they have allowed our area to decline – and it is simply not in the interest of a Labour MP to improve the town. That’s why the streets are littered. That’s why the town centre is moribund.

I’ve already met with the Teesside Mayor to get his backing for my economic strategy to reinvigorate Darlington – and I will back his proposals for Teesside Airport because we need the transport links, jobs and growth it will bring.

We have the opportunity of an MP working with Boris Johnston to make sure Darlington benefits as we leave the EU. Someone who has the ear of ministers.

Someone who has real ambition for this great place.

Please give me that opportunity. I won’t let this town down.

I grew up off North Road, I'm from the town & I love it.

I've spent 10 years winning campaigns across the country & learning from the best changemakers in the country. Every time I speak to someone from Darlington they tell me the same story about their pride in our town, how the community here is friendly and full of great talent and how it's a great place to make a life, but sadly they tell me that the reality is the town has gone downhill in recent years. People are struggling to get by and we're being let down on the basic tests of a good life.

I know that Darlington has a bright future and that if we listen to our community and business leaders together we can make things better and celebrate our rich history. It's time for a change and I'm campaigning to make sure that whatever part of Darlington you're born in, whichever school you go to, everyone gets a fair crack at a decent life for them and their families.

I'd love to hear from you so please get in touch to tell me how you think we can make Darlington fulfil its potential.

I moved to Darlington in 1997. I worked as a senior sales manager for a national retailer before starting a family. I’m now the father of three school age children and my partner, Catriona, works in the chemical industry.

I have campaigned for environmental justice for two decades helping to set up community allotments, orchards and wildflower meadows. I coordinate an award winning road safety campaign and I work for bike hire and bike recycling groups.

I joined The Green Party when it became clear that I had been asking the wrong people to do the right thing. Now it is time to put the right people into parliament.

Darlington will benefit greatly from Green Party policies.

A fair economy - we have the skills and industry that are ready to transform our region with a stable economy that is run in everyone’s best interest. A Public NHS in national hands. The current plans to reduce A&E and maternity provision in our region are based on the fundamentally flawed STP and must be reversed. Decent housing for the Borough. New houses should be built to the highest energy efficiency levels. Better transport is needed because the 10,000 new home planned for Darlington could put 25,000 more cars on our roads. Our roads are at gridlock and air pollution levels are dangerously high. Free Education and teachers free to teach. Headteachers recently wrote to Darlington parents warning of the consequences of underfunding.

I am extremely proud to have been chosen to represent my hometown of Darlington. I worked closely with the previous Reform UK spokesman for Darlington and am well aware of the issues facing people in our great town. I was born and raised in Darlington. I spent my childhood living on Clifton Road and then moved to Geneva Drive. I now live in the Hundens Lane area of Darlington with my wife. I am an English teacher who has spent over ten years helping children achieve their potential. I have worked at a school in Bishop Auckland and several other schools in the North of England. I have also been fortunate to have taught in other countries, including the USA, Kazakhstan, and South Korea. I volunteered in orphanages, helping some of the most impoverished children take their first steps to a better life. My work is extremely rewarding, and it would take a lot for me to even think about leaving my job, but I can no longer sit in silence and watch our country be torn apart. I have been an active campaigner in Darlington for many years, knocking on doors and organising community events. The majority of people tell me the same thing; “We must stop illegal immigration. They are laughing at us.”  “Why are we spending money keeping foreign criminals in this country? Why aren’t we deporting them?”  “Why are we giving foreign aid to China and India when people in our country are homeless?” “Why is my tax going up and the level of services going down?” I’ve decided to stand in this election because the country we love needs us. At this election, you finally have a choice. If Labour gets in, our borders will be wide open. The Conservatives have failed us. Only Reform UK has the policies to save our country. Only Reform UK will deliver the change this country needs. But this election isn't about me. It is about you, the voter. Your vote is precious; vote for something you believe in rather than the lesser of two evils. This town and you, the people, have masses of potential. What we need is a politician who believes in the people of this town, who will put Darlington first, and who has not been parachuted in by their party's Head Office. We have a Labour leader who believes a woman can have a penis; if he can lie about that, he will lie about everything, and a Conservative government who have proved time after time that they are incapable of governing. I want to give a voice to the tens of thousands of people in Darlington who feel all politicians are the same. Politicians have stopped listening to the people. I will listen and act upon your concerns. Your views are not wrong. They are held by the majority of people.  You know this because you have daily conversations with your friends and neighbours who agree with you. If you demand a better country with politicians who feel exactly the same way you do, please vote REFORM UK on 4th July, and let's change this country for the better. Remember: Your vote is precious. Labour and Conservatives will try and scare you into thinking a vote for Reform UK is a wasted vote, but it isn’t. If enough people vote Reform UK, then we will win in Darlington.  Always best wishes Michael

From my first campaign visits to Dartford as a neighbouring Labour parliamentary candidate more than 20 years ago to recent work alongside local activists and our excellent councillors to help win borough council seats for Labour, I have developed a passion for the town and its people.

That's why I'm delighted to be standing to be Dartford's next MP

Dartford has been badly let down by the Tories and the town urgently needs a Labour government and local MP who will stand up on behalf of local people and fight to save our NHS, for safer streets, an end to the cost of living crisis and for genuinely affordable new homes for local people.

I have a track record in South East London in my role as councillor and campaigner for local communities including delivering big pay increases for low paid care workers and helping transform mental health services. I will bring the same commitment to social justice for local people after 14 wasted years under the Tories.

My partner Nicola is a secondary school teacher in a large local comprehensive school and our children who both went to south east London state schools and are now studying at university. I come from an armed services family and believe the UK needs strong defence and robust borders.



Priorities for change

My five priorities for change are those that Dartford residents have been telling party campaigners about on the doorsteps:

* Undoing the Tory damage to our NHS and care services, with rapid high-quality treatment for residents and an end to the current record long waits

* Housing for all with new build homes provided at genuinely affordable and social rents, help for people of all ages onto the housing ladder and an end to homelessness

* Fighting crime with more local police and with Dartford residents made safer from anti-social behaviour and violence against women and girls

* Getting Dartford moving by fighting for improved train and bus services as part of a wider Labour plan to support local people through the transition to Net Zero

* Taking 'Pride in Dartford' as the fastest growing UK town which now needs to see investment in high streets, support for SMEs, local skills and the arts

favourite_biscuit: A vegan chocolate digestive dipped in tea!
statement_to_voters:
Laura has been a councillor in Newtown since 2019, and in 2023 stood in the May Local Elections as a Green Party representative for her ward, winning her seat again to stand as Dartford’s first Green Party councillor. 

Born and brought up in Dartford, Laura attended a local comprehensive, studied early years in further education and now works in a special educational needs (SEND) setting. 

Laura first became involved in politics through community projects, and continues to be active in organising these. Through this, she noticed that the lack of equality and unequal distribution of wealth that she was seeing were linked to political choices. This has been a driving force for her. 

Laura joined the Green Party in 2021, leaving the Labour Party as she felt that they were not offering strong enough policies on environmental and social issues. 

Since then, Laura has worked hard for Dartford borough, including proposals for reduction of glyphosate chemicals used for weed management, supporting local housing needs, and fighting for the protection of green spaces including Swanscombe Peninsula; she was instrumental in setting up the successful grassroots campaign Save Swanscombe Peninsula. She recently founded the Dartford Care Backpacks initiative which collects donated essentials items to give out to homeless individuals in need. 

Laura has also run a community safety group for several years, and is a strong voice for justice and peace. She has a Jewish heritage, and has been deeply troubled by the conflict, and the loss of Palestinian lives in Gaza, working with others to hold a vigil to bringing together people from all communities to reject hate, promote peace, and call for an immediate and lasting ceasefire. 

Laura sees standing for the Green Party as the only way to create a fairer, greener, and more socially just society. 

Laura is the Green Party’s candidate for Dartford at the next General Election.

Jonathan has lived in Brixworth since 1998 and has run his leadership and change management consultancy since 2002,  following a corporate career in a number of FTSE 100 organisations. Jonathan was elected to Daventry District Council on the first occasion of standing in July 2019 with a 33% swing from the sitting Conservative.  He believes passionately in standing up for the voices of local people.   In his spare time he loves playing and listening to music and is an enthusiastic photographer.

I’m committed to achieving a fairer, greener world in which my family can thrive, with an optimistic future. I trained as a pharmacist and now work as a medical writer, but also serve on the Parish Council in Bugbrooke. Since becoming a Councillor in 2021, I’ve helped to establish the Environmental Working Group, which focuses on the practicalities and challenges of a community seeking to live sustainably, by organising litter picks, re-use days and other initiatives. As a founding member of Climate Action West Northamptonshire, I write for the online forum and host climate cafes to support people who feel frustrated and worried about the climate crisis. I strongly believe that with the right government policy and leadership, we can have a just and positive transition to a safer, sustainable society with a greater quality of life for all. This is my motivation for standing for parliamentary election for the second time in Daventry, where I hope to build on the increased vote share I won in 2019, up by 2.4% from 2017. Having listened to the frustrations of many local residents through my voluntary work over the past few years, I’m delighted is to be able to give people of the Daventry constituency the opportunity to vote Green.

favourite_biscuit: Jammie Dodgers aka Boris Biscuits, apparently ....
statement_to_voters:
More About the Candidate from https://www.derbyshiredalesconservatives.org.uk/sarah-dines-bio

I am a family lawyer and mother of 4 grown-up sons. I have been a lifelong Conservative who benefitted greatly from Conservative policies which socially and economically enfranchised millions of people within the United Kingdom. I was born in Billericay and raised in Basildon, Essex. My grandparents on both sides were farmers and small holders. My parents were tenant farmers until their farm was taken from them to form part of what then became Basildon new town – something which left me with a life-long interest in the rights of the individual versus the state.

I grew up in a council house and went to a comprehensive school and then on to Brunel University and the Inns of Court School of Law. A member of Lincoln’s Inn, I was called to the bar in 1988 and established myself as a family law practitioner, dealing with divorce, care, adoption, child abduction and related issues. I have had local government experience, having served as a Basildon District Councillor, and contested the parliamentary seat of East Belfast in the 1997 Election. I am passionately committed to the countryside and the environment and am part of the “Vote Blue, Go Green” movement within the Conservative Party. I also think it is important to support all sections of the rural community.

As someone who has benefitted from the National Health Service, I am absolutely committed to increases in its funding to meet the growing demands of an ageing population that is also living longer, with multiple health needs. I voted Leave in the 2016 Referendum and strongly believe that trust in Parliament and politicians will not be restored until the result of that Referendum is delivered by the United Kingdom leaving the European Union. I have been living and campaigning in the Derbyshire Dales since I was selected as the Conservative Candidate on 7 November. My thirty years of experience as a family lawyer has meant that I have dealt with many of the issues facing today’s society. I have represented many people with the assistance of Legal Aid. I am particularly interested in supporting young and vulnerable families and the elderly.

In addition to trying to meet as many people as possible in Derbyshire Dales on the doorsteps, on the pavements, in the shops and on farms, I have also been in constant touch with County Councillors, District Councillors and Parish Councillors with regards to day to day issues facing the Derbyshire Dales.

Are you sick and tired of Politics and Politicians? I certainly am.  

That’s why I’m standing as an INDEPENDENT candidate ~ to give YOU the choice of a representative in Parliament who can speak powerfully in the best interests of the PEOPLE of Derbyshire Dales – and NOT Big Corporate agendas.

Here are just some of the National issues which you the PEOPLE of Derbyshire Dales have told me are most important to you...   

Cost of Living Crisis  

You may be old enough to remember the assurances which we were given to justify the privatisation of all our key national industries.  That everything would be far more efficient, as well as cheaper, under Big Corporate control.  Yet the price of everything from electricity to food to fuel to travel has skyrocketed in recent years.  Meanwhile, those same Big Corporations are delivering bumper profits for their shareholders.  I was in Portugal recently and a return train fare for a 2.5hour journey, bought on the day, was just 40EUROS !!! A whole breakfast for less than 5EUROS. We have to reclaim control of our key essential industries, and return them back to the PEOPLE.  

Decimation of the NHS  

What was once a nourishing and joyful National Health Service has now been taken over by management consultants, following Big Pharma protocols.  You only have to look at Pfizer’s £100,000,000,000 profits in 2022 to realise the extent to which Big Corporations are draining monies from the PEOPLE worldwide.  Yet, somehow, those same Big Pharma companies have been relieved of any liability for harms caused by their products.  We, the PEOPLE, are left footing the huge (and growing) bill for the burgeoning number of compensation claims resulting from the experimental, not-fully-tested, novel MRNA technology injections, rushed through in 2020.  What’s truly needed is a restoration of the vitality of the Nation ~ combined with embracing natural healing protocols. A return of the heart into our NHS.    

Threat of WW3  

Did YOU agree to support Israel in its massacre of innocent women and children in Palestine? And were you as outraged as I was to discover that earlier this year Rishi Sumac agreed to send a further £2,500,000,000 of OUR money in funding to Ukraine – on top of the £4,600,000,000 which has already been paid to them?  And now there is talk of military conscription for our children, advice to keep a stock of tinned food 'in case of emergency' and the very real prospect of becoming embroiled in WorldWar3 and the threat of nuclear war.  If anything, Keir Starmer is even more Authoritarian than Rishi Sunak.  Let’s cease our involvement in endless overseas conflicts and prioritise our resources on looking after the PEOPLE of the UK.   

Watch my video commentaries on many of these key issues at www.rachelelnaugh.com/Love-Derbyshire-Dales

Here are just some of the Local issues which you the PEOPLE of Derbyshire Dales have told me are most important to you...   

Supporting our Farmers to Thrive  

Farming is one of the key sectors underpinning our area.  Yet our farmers are suffering from excessive DEFRA rules and regulations, combined with rising costs and lack of access to capital. As your INDEPENDENT MP for Derbyshire Dales I will be a powerful voice for radical transformation in all the ways we can value and support our farming community.  No Farmers = No Food.  Watch my video interview of local farmers at www.rachelelnaugh.com/Love-Derbyshire-Dales [coming soon]   

Embracing Tourism and Tourists  

Around 5million visitors flood into Derbyshire Dales every year to reconnect with Nature.  Yet very little has been done to support the infrastructure required to manage such a huge annual influx of people.  Let’s fully embrace all our guests to the area!  Let’s find innovative ways to take cars off the road by restoring the railways to the region.  And let’s creatively manage the number of second and holiday homes (which are ripping the heart and soul out of many local communities) - while ensuring there is ample guest accommodation.  Watch my video interview re: Restoring the Railways at www.rachelelnaugh.com/Love-Derbyshire-Dales [coming soon]   

Restoring Heart and Soul to Derbyshire Dales  

The draconian regime of Peak District National Park ‘Authority’ has unfortunately had the effect of turning the area into a Museum.  None of the great architectural wonders created by the Victorians (which are now listed buildings and conservation areas) would ever have been given permission had PDNPA existed at the time.  What’s needed is an innovative and visionary overhaul which both honours landowners Common Law rights and the natural environment, whilst also ensuring that local people can enjoy affordable housing.  People are PART of Nature!  Watch my video interrogation of PDNPA CEO Phil Mulligan at www.rachelelnaugh.com/Love-Derbyshire-Dales    

 As your INDEPENDENT MP I will host fortnightly public meetings so that we can debate all the key issues YOU are facing.  As a highly experienced public speaker I will then powerfully voice your concerns/needs in Parliament, whilst ensuring that at all times I act and vote in the best interests of the PEOPLE of Derbyshire Dales.

 Your vote CAN make a difference! 

Imagine if everyone disillusioned with Politics and Politicians voted for an INDEPENDENT candidate in the General Election?

Together, we can make 4 July 2024 INDEPENDENT’S DAY !!!

VOTE Rachel Elnaugh-LOVE

Helen is married with three children and four grandchildren. Managing Director of a successful, company delivering services to schools and local government, she has worked at Chesterfield College and in Children’s Services as a Senior Officer in various parts of the country.

Working in adult learning and community development reflects her passion to support talents and skills of local people. She has managed high profile schools building projects including one of the largest in the country and her own life experience shows that education and being given opportunities to broaden horizons is the key to successful and fulfilling lives.

She has a deep love for the countryside and Derbyshire is where she was born (in a caravan on a farm) and where she loves to be. Her interest in politics has grown out of disillusionment for the current two-party, broken system; we can do better by being true and fair.

Helen's local priorities are:

Farming policies and promises made and broken from Brexit – lack of central government leadership and no coherent strategy.

Rural poverty – isolation and lack of support for families and elderly.

Second homes driving up house prices and driving out local people.

Councillor Alan Graves is standing as the Reform UK party candidate in the election, and says his top priority would be getting rid of the new Combined County Authority which is being created.

Cllr Graves says a referendum should have been held to ask people whether they wanted devolution for the area in the first place.

People weren’t given the chance to say whether we need a combined authority, so they will have the chance to show their opposition when they vote. There are far too many politicians – everyone agrees with that. I don’t know anyone who’s happy with how many we’ve got.

I am a very dedicated person, and I will take the powers of the position seriously if I am elected mayor. However, my top priority is working towards getting the position abolished. I will aim to get the people of Derbyshire and Nottinghamshire a better deal and save taxpayers’ money.

Simon grew up in rural North Yorkshire before moving to London to attend university. After a spell working in our capital city, he returned to Yorkshire, this time settling in the mill town of Dewsbury. He has made his home here for 20 years, along with his wife Marnie and their two daughters, both of whom attend a local secondary school. As well as his work in the audio visual industry, Simon has also in the past found time to play a pivotal part in the formation of the fan-owned cooperative football club Scarborough Athletic, and served as its first volunteer chair. In addition he served on the board of the national body for Supporters’ Trusts, Supporters Direct, which provides helps provide support and guidance to sports fans seeking to gain ownership and/or board influence of the clubs they follow. In recent years, he has served as a governor of Boothroyd Primary Academy in Dewsbury, gaining first-hand experience of the pressures the education system is under. Having never previously been a dyed-in-the-wool supporter of any particular party, Simon joined the Green Party after researching their policies and realising they actually made a lot of sense. His mission is to get the Green message across to Dewsbury voters!

I have lived in Culham in South Oxfordshire for 17 years, after periods in Spain, London and, originally, Cheshire. I work as a Public Health professional working in Oxfordshire County Council, specialising in drug & alcohol treatment services. Having studied politics and philosophy at university, I have been involved in environmental & animal rights campaigning for many years.

I was elected as District Councillor for Sandford and the WIttenhams in 2019 with 73% of the vote. I chair the District's Climate and Ecological Emergencies committee and I am the Cycle and Active Travel Champion for the District. I am a parish councillor as well as a District Councillor, campaigning with the local community on over-development, more active travel infrastructure and local climate mitigation actions such as hedgerow and tree planting, achieving lower speed limits, and new bus routes. I was also a governor at John Mason school for 5 years and am now a member of Abingdon Learning Trust.

We are in a climate and ecological emergency and this needs to be the overriding concern of all those in any level of power and government. I want to stand so Green Party priorities and policies continue to be implemented and to continue the great work Green councillors have done in the last 4 years in alliance.

Olly Glover lives in Milton and is a senior consultant working on improving railways. He is a parish councillor in his village, and volunteers as a visitor to people living with motor neurone disease. Through his work and volunteering, Olly has a long record of serving the public and understanding people’s needs and frustrations. Olly’s priorities for the constituency are holding the government to account during the cost of living crisis, improving access to healthcare, and ensuring our schools are properly funded.

Mocky is passionate about the climate, education, supporting our local businesses, providing a voice to those that are underrepresented and protecting our great NHS, trade unions and welfare system.



Since 2017, Mocky has been the Labour Leader on South Oxfordshire and Didcot Town Councils. Mocky is tackling the issues that affect residents, he has been fighting for improved amenities and infrastructure such as dentists, schools and GP surgeries and lobbying for a new minor injuries unit at Didcot Community Hospital.



Mocky shares the frustrations that residents have with the current planning system. Houses are being built by developers without an adequate number of affordable homes and without joined-up thinking. This must change!



Mocky is concerned that our young people are not getting the opportunities to fulfil their potential and that our vulnerable residents in our community are being forgotten. Also, he wants to enhance the connectivity between our towns and villages by improving cycle lanes and by having better public transport links.



Mocky lives in Didcot with his wife and two young daughters. Mocky is a Chartered Marketer, a Fellow of the Chartered Institute of Marketing. Mocky is a trustee and volunteer for several local charities and groups, he runs a community centre and is a governor at Didcot Girls School. Mocky is halfway through a PhD researching culture, identity, religion, and young people.



Mocky is keen to hear your views, learn about your priorities and what you care about. Please feel free to email him on mocky.wantlabour@outlook



After 14 years of Tory misrule, we need change -- positive, creative change for our community and the world around us. Mocky Khan for Didcot and Wantage.

It's a privilege to have been selected as your Liberal Democrat Prospective Parliamentary Candidate for Doncaster Central.

The county of Yorkshire is very close to my heart. My mum's side of the family have lived and worked in Yorkshire for several generations and my family hails from the Leeds, Bradford and Hull areas. Some of my most cherished childhood memories are of weekends and holidays spent with family visiting towns, museums, historical sites and outdoor spaces across Yorkshire.

I have been heavily involved in community and volunteer work throughout my adult life, twice as a governor of both a local secondary and primary school, and as a trustee of a charity which owns and manages an historic house, park and gardens near to my home. As a huge sports fan, a particular highlight of my volunteerism was my role as an Olympic Gamesmaker in 2012!

I am passionate about green issues and tackling climate change, and as a dad to 3 young kids a key priority for me is maintaining and safeguarding local parks and green spaces (particularly in urban areas), something so important for the mental and physical health and wellbeing of residents.

Like many people across the United Kingdom I'm experiencing longer wait times for NHS medical and dental treatment, and the daily challenges of soaring energy bills, high food prices, rising mortgage interest rates and astronomical inflation rates that are eroding my savings and sending the cost of living sky rocketing. All of these issues have been caused by years of Tory mismanagement of our economy and under investment in our public services. I am a long time supporter and campaigner for the Liberal Democrats, and in May 2022 I stood as a candidate in the local council elections. Together with my fellow candidates we knocked on over 6,000 doors in our ward, trebled our vote share, and pushed the Tories into third place!

post_label: Doncaster East and the Isle of Axholme
Doncaster East and the Isle of Axholme
Doncaster East and the Isle of Axholme
Doncaster East and the Isle of Axholme
statement_to_voters: It's a huge privilege to be the Labour Party's Candidate for the new constituency of Doncaster East and the Isle of Axholme. It's where I live, where my family have grown up, children have gone to school, where we work, and where I've been a community champion, volunteering in lots of different organisations for many years. I love this place and the people. I am determined to apply my many years of experience in business, starting on the front line, with deep knowledge of my community, lived experience, and my passion to drive change in order to make lives better in every area of the constituency that I will hopefully be elected to serve.

post_label: Doncaster East and the Isle of Axholme
statement_to_voters:
Nicola Turner has lives in the Colne Valley with her family and knows the area very well. Nicola has long experience in manufacturing and, more recently, has embarked on a career as an NHS professional. 
Nicola is a well-known campaigner who is very active in taking up local issues on behalf of residents.
She has fought changes to HRI for over 15 years! Firstly, when a Labour Government down graded the Maternity unit and began the series of attempts by Government to reduce the HRI to a cottage hospital which is totally unsuitable and unacceptable to Huddersfield and the Colne Valley.
Nicola is closely involved in the community life of the Colne Valley and is always ready to help individual residents with their problems and concerns.
The Colne Valley absolutely depends on good roads to enable residents and businesses thrive. The potholed roads that are endured are the consequence of under investment by Government, as well as Kirklees Labour choosing not to provide sufficient funding for basic repairs to keep our roads safe. The Lib Dems proposed an extra £1m every year to help mend our roads but Labour refused to do so.
And then there is the constant issue that the Council under Labour appears unable to understand. This is that roads in the hills of the Colne Valley suffer more and more often from below zero temperatures and therefore need to be gritted more often. There are simple solutions using basic technology that will identify when roads need to be gritted but Labour seem incapable of appreciating its importance.
Introducing car park charges in Marsden and Slaithwaite is another blow for the local economy. Many businesses depend on visitors trade and local people dropping by for a mini shop. Charging to park will put these businesses at risk.
there's much that needs to be done. Nicola has the energy and commitment to provide the real leadership that the Colne Valley needs.

I am a former solider (Regimental Sergeant Major) who now runs several successful companies in the energy sector, and I know how to create jobs and build businesses from scratch. The Reform Party UK have graciously allowed me to stand unimpeded, so the people of Doncaster North have a real alternative, to the failed duopoly of Con-Lab. I will push back against mass immigration that is set to change our country forever. If you need foreign workers you issue a work visa, and they don't bring their family...This happens in every country, instead of giving passports out like sweeties. I will also fight the UK's totally unrealistic and unnecessary NET ZERO folly. It will bankrupt us!  My priority for the people of Doncaster is to boost skills training for young people. Our bloated university sector needs to be slimmed down. Instead, greater investment is needed in apprenticeships and vocational skills – urgently required to re-build our industrial base. We need real jobs to produce real things.

I work in IT support and software development. I have family roots in Whitby going back hundreds of years. I have been an active member of Whitby Town Council for the last three years.

If I am elected I will represent all Whitby residents, whatever their political views, and will work for the best deal for Whitby. I will hold regular surgeries and keep in touch with residents with regular newsletters all year round.

Bio Lisa Scott Lisa has been resident in Hookwood for nearly 20 years, the past 7 of which, she has been working for the community in the form of Parish Councillor, spearheading such projects as Community Speed Watch and low-traffic residential areas.  Lisa was motivated to move in to politics when Mole Valley became the target of unwelcome interest from the oil exploration industry which further threatens the climate, Green Belt, and the air and land around our homes. The possible risks of this extractive industry have become even more apparent with the recent earthquake swarms that have already caused damage to homes and brought worry to residents. Lisa has worked to improve cycling and walking infrastructure and accessibility, with the intention of making walking and cycling a feasible travel option for any member of the community. An 800 signature petition triggered initiation of upgrading of the deteriorated pavement along the A217 to national standards for shared use, bringing it back in to use for those wishing to have an alternatine to car use. Lisa believes passionately that the key to a positive future is through strong and caring local communities. Protecting and promoting local trades, businesses and services to create local jobs for local people. Lisa supports a Work From Home culture to reduce the pressure to commute. Less commuting would result in less traffic on our heaving road system, less pollution of our air and a reclamation of the hours spent on the daily commute to a faceless office building. That extra personal time can lead to an increase in loyalty and respect for our home areas, as we get to spend more time in the place we live, with our families. Lisa is also a keen home cook, allotmenter and travels by bike whenever possible. She made a learning project of transforming a draughty Edwardian shop in to a cosy home, future proofed for energy efficiency.

I do not want my hard-earned taxes wasted on ridiculous policies that never come into effect, like Rwanda, and frivolous government spending.  Every one of my tax pennies must count, unfortunately this and previous governments have failed us; central government wastage is rife and it has to stop. Reform UK wants to save at least 5p in every pound by reducing government wastage. I want to go further and save 15p in every pound. For every 5p saved, that would mean £50billion per year can be used to reduce the heavy burden we all share on paying taxes and allow for investment in Britain.

As a Liberal Democrat County Council Candidate for Deal and Walmer I back the six priorities of Kent Liberal Democrats which are:
- Protecting our green spaces
- Improving care provision
- Ensuring every child can go to a good school
- Making our streets safer
- Restoring and improving public transport systems
- Promoting better mental and physical health

Caring for our community, our environment and our residents are key priorities for Kent Liberal Democrats. They have never been more important than now as we emerge from the pandemic.

Protecting the natural environment is of huge concern. We have a responsibility to our children to ensure the world they inherit is safe and clean. As County Councillor I will focus on protecting our precious green spaces and encouraging biodiversity. I will ensure new housing/business developments are properly thought out in terms of services and transport; that any new housing is sustainable as well as energy efficient and that the environmental impact of any development is rigorously evaluated. I will also be looking at air quality and ways to improve it in Deal, Walmer and Dover, which are heavily impacted by Channel traffic.

Another area of concern is the level of traffic and speeding. We urgently need to make our streets safer for all. I will actively promote 20mph as the default speed limit in areas outside schools, residential and shopping districts. Better local transport feeds into this and I shall be urging for a fresh focus on improving existing bus routes and developing new ones.

Our Green Party policies include:   -Investment in cheaper, cleaner energy, and good jobs providing it   -Publicly owned utilities run for people not profit, including water & rail.   -A wealth tax on the super rich because of huge wealth inequality.   -Protection for tenants, affordable homes and council houses in the right places.   -Protection for wildlife & farmland with real teeth.   -Re-investment in a public NHS capable of retaining and recruiting staff.   -Cleaner government with fairer voting.  -Scrapping the 2 child benefit cap -Protection of workers rights, Especially important to Dovorians after the mass sackings by P&O   -Defence of human rights at home and abroad. 

A vote for me and for Green Party policies is a vote for REAL change. My legal training gives me the skills to speak up for Dover, Deal & villages. I grew up, and raise my family here, so I understand the full range of our local issues.  We’re proud our party doesn’t get its money from self-seeking multi-millionaires, or from big corporate lobbies. We’re funded by ordinary local citizens.  Since 2019 we’ve held 10 seats on town councils in Dover district. Wins that put us third party in this district. Wins that mean we can work hard on local actions for people in Dover Deal & Walmer.   Across Kent, since 2021, the Green Party has won 54 seats of district councils, and 5 seats at Kent County Council.

Being born and raised in Dover has helped me see its potential  -I will donate 40% of the MP Salary back into community development  -Bring tourism and jobs, boost local economy   -Heath care solutions, fix the NHS -Education and youth services to tackle antisocial     behaviour   -Environmental sustainability  Full details below.     There is a big list of things we need to address in this country. I believe in nationalisation of services.  Housing needs better regulation and the cost of living can come down. Dedicated community advocate and Dover resident. Running as an independent candidate,  committing to putting people before politics and advocating for the needs of local residents. With a background deeply rooted in community service. My campaign focuses on bringing positive change to the constituency, addressing pressing issues and championing the voices of all residents.   -Donate 40% of the MP salary back into the community before taxes, reinvesting in the District supporting local initiatives. As an independent I prioritises the interests of residents above party politics, ensuring that every decision made is in the best interest of the community. I want to setup youth councils and citizens assemblies.  -Bring tourism and jobs: Proposing initiatives to support local businesses and foster economic growth in Dover. A major component of this plan is promoting Dover's     historical sites and heritage. By promoting and enhancing the area's rich history with aims to boost tourism and create jobs, thereby strengthening the local economy.   -Healthcare: Advocating for improved access to healthcare services and facilities for residents of all backgrounds. Changes must happen from the ground up, supporting healthcare staff and advocates who are on the front lines of service delivery.  -Education and Youth services: Committing to improving education, ensuring every child has access to quality schooling and opportunities for personal growth. I believe that educational improvements should come from the ground up, empowering teachers and educational advocates to drive change within the system.  -Environmental Sustainability: Promoting environmentally friendly policies and initiatives to protect Dover's natural resources and combat climate change. I advocate for using our colleges and schools to build youth councils and citizen assemblies to      investigate new processes, utilising our own local champions to lead these efforts.

Mike comes from a background of service, he served in the Army where he deployed on three Operational tours, at the National Crime Agency where he focussed on combatting serious and organised crime and most recently with the Ministry of Defence where he worked in a Counter Terrorist role.

Mike will stand up for the people of Dover & Deal, giving them a strong voice in Parliament.

Hello, I’m Ian Flynn and I’m delighted to be standing as the Liberal Democrat candidate for Dudley North. I live here in the Black Country with my wife and young family.

We have fallen further behind London and the South East in terms of incomes and investment. While progress is being made in the West Midlands overall, it seems to be taking a while to filter down to Dudley Borough and Dudley North. I cannot believe we’re still looking at the eyesore Cavendish House and what to do with Dudley Hippodrome remains unresolved.

I’d like to see more done to support the high street and even the playing field with the digital retailers, and to repurpose our town centres to better protect our local communities. We’re the fifth largest economy in the world, so we shouldn’t have young people sleeping rough on our streets.

As your MP I would work to empower and unite the local community, to access better educational opportunities for all, tackle our adult social care and mental health challenges, and protect the environment for our young people’s futures.

Pete has been a Lambeth Green Councillor for Gipsy Hill ward, where he lives, since 2018. Before moving to Lambeth in 2008, Pete spent 22 years as an engineer in the army and RAF.

Pete is passionate about standing up for local people and protecting their public services. In 2016 he became a candidate in the Gipsy Hill by-election after occupying the Carnegie Library for 10 days. Shortly afterwards he moved into one of the six Lambeth council estates scheduled for demolition and regeneration, to support residents fighting to keep their homes.

Since becoming a Councillor, Pete has worked with residents and Lambeth Officers to improve the quality of housing in the borough. He is well-known as a housing champion, particularly for those in temporary accommodation. Pete is constantly challenging systemic inequality, to ensure all of Lambeth’s residents have equal access not only to housing, but also to jobs, justice, health, and education.

Pete is also committed to tackling the illegally high levels of air pollution in the borough. Air quality is both an environmental and public health emergency. It affects all residents but particularly children, the elderly, and other vulnerable people. He has studied the transformations needed to achieve clean air and carbon neutrality across the borough by 2030, and is committed to implementing these.

In his free time, Pete is a keen runner and cyclist. He has completed more than 150 marathons and ultra-marathons.

I got actively involved in politics in 2014 when I saw how badly the residents of Cressingham Gardens were being treated by Lambeth Council. Their homes were going to be demolished and their councillors just weren't listening to them. I believe all Lambeth's residents have a right to be heard, and to good quality, affordable housing.

Pete Elliott

Growing up my family positively encouraged freedom of speech, open mindedness, self expression in any form and kindness. No surprise then, my first vote went to the SDP!

Lambeth has been home for fifteen years, as a wife and a mother, I encourage the same values within my family. Like many Liberal Democrats today my activist career began in the wake of the Brexit Referendum. The experience gave me the opportunity to promote liberal values into my community. It was a privilege working with the Streatham team in the 2019 general election campaign, I bundled, phoned, canvassed, coordinated, counted and supported the candidate in her speaking and community engagements. The experience showed me the true value of what can be achieved when you engage with the community. So when Lambeth declared a Climate Emergency in January 2019 I grasped the chance of representing the Party within the ‘Beyond Politics’ group to hold the Council to account, secure a Citizens Assembly & ensure a Climate Action Plan for Lambeth.

I am standing to be your candidate because I want to see that Action Plan implemented - for the health and wellbeing of all within Lambeth. This year’s tragic events have forced another narrative into the public consciousness something close to my heart: Violence against women & girls, I was on the working group who successfully moved the motion at Conference. 

Equally, all too often the safety and wellbeing of young boys and men is overlooked by society. Personal experience has shown me firsthand why it's so important we support boys and men in our community, from a young age to ensure they have the tools not just to survive but to thrive. Lambeth Council must take meaningful action so that everyone in our community can be safe at all times.

As your candidate, I would use my platform to demand this. Working many years in the Fashion industry - for global companies and running my own business has shown it is not enough to care passionately. Making things happen requires organisation, motivation and hard work. I can bring this to our campaign and into the Town Hall.

I am a lifelong resident who has worked with local businesses and residents all my career. I am here to challenge the chaos and current instability we have in Scotland and Westminster with disconnected and divided governments and uncertainty of Labour policies.  We need to be addressing the serious questions about whether our governments are presently undermining our country including our farmers, our countryside, our climate and our health. Are we to work together or in confrontation? I came in to politics for the sake of my children and we need to look long term, not just seek short term 'fixes'.

Dumfries & Galloway matters to me. It's where I was born, raised, and all my family live there.



But our are is being let down by two chaotic Governments, too busy fighting among themselves, instead of fighting for Dumfries & Galloway. Enough is enough. It's time for change.



Dumfries & Galloway can lead the way in ending the division and decline of the SNP and the Tories by helping elect a Labour government that will make change a reality. The SNP say they want to send a message to Westminster. I want to change the government in Westminster and you can only do that by voting Labour. We can have a Labour MP at the heart of the next Labour Government as well as the heart of our community. For too long Dumfries & Galloway has been the forgotten region.



Polls show Labour can win back the seat. The last time there was a Labour Government (indeed until 2015) Labour held the seat with Russell Brown winning 46% of the vote (no party has achieved this since).



I will fight for action to tackle the cost of living crisis and get the economy back on track, so local people have more money in their pocket, and we can invest in protecting our local NHS.



Note: James was born and raised in Dumfries, attending Loreburn Primary then Dumfries Academy before studying law at Edinburgh University. Having worked as a lawyer for eight years specialising in pensions (also qualifying in New York, USA), he retrained as an independent financial adviser and has been a chartered financial planner since 2020.

PRESS RELEASE – SCOTTISH BORDERS GREENS FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE	31st JANUARY 2024			 SCOTTISH GREENS ANNOUNCE CANDIDATE FOR DUMFRIESSHIRE, CLYDESDALE AND TWEEDDALE

✔	Former Holyrood and Council candidate Dominic Ashmole selected by membership. ✔	“Time to break with the past, build resilience in our communities, and face a difficult future with solidarity and compassion.” ✔	South Scotland campaign launch attended by co-leader Patrick Harvie and other Green MSPs.

The Scottish Greens have named their candidate for the constituency of Dumfriesshire, Clydesdale and Tweeddale in the upcoming UK General Election. Former healthcare technology project manager Dominic Ashmole, who stood previously in the Holyrood and Council elections, was selected following a ballot of party members throughout Dumfries & Galloway, South Lanarkshire and the Scottish Borders.

At a South Scotland campaign launch in Tweedbank last weekend, Mr Ashmole said:

“I’m grateful to party members for this new opportunity to represent the Greens. When I stood for the Council in 2022, our vote share trebled to more than 16%. I believe we can build on that momentum and send a serious message to Westminster.” 

“Many voters have lost faith in the traditional parties. They don’t want a government that blames refugees and abandons climate action. Nor can they support others who continue promoting false hopes and a reckless growth agenda that has undermined the Earth’s capacity to sustain life.”

“Greens recognise that to live through these times, we must move beyond a global system that is fuelled by exploitation and consumerism, and controlled by the super-rich.”

“Last election, the Conservatives only narrowly beat the SNP here, and voters might assume it’s still a two horse race. But both of those parties have massively lost support since then.”  

“So I'm asking voters to back a dark, Green horse. Let's shock the system that is failing us. Let's make this election about us setting out on a new path. Because we will need to turn to each other as we live through the difficult times the political elites have led us into.” 

“A vote for the Greens is for the courage to break with the past, to build resilience in our communities, and to face a difficult future with solidarity and compassion.”

Mr Ashmole was speaking at a South Scotland campaign launch attended by Scottish Greens Co-Leader Patrick Harvie MSP, Maggie Chapman MSP (Justice, Equality, Human Rights and Economy), and Ariane Burgess MSP (Communities, Land Reform, Housing and Rural Affairs).

Having grown up in a working class family in the countryside, I know what it is like to be at the back of the queue for investment in roads, public services and a decent internet connection. I remember freezing winters without heating - I never thought that this country would return to those dark days. But now too many people in Dumfriesshire, Clydesdale and Tweeddale and across Scotland are struggling; whether through being on a long NHS waiting list, the cost of living crisis or the cost for many sectors, including retail, distribution and farming, of doing business.



I am an experienced economist having worked in the civil service and the private sector on economic growth, industrial strategy, competition and regulation. I want individuals and both the private and public sectors to thrive, generating the jobs and prosperity that we need and deserve, and I have the background to help to deliver this for Scotland and the UK.
