Hello, I am Shockat Adam, and I am honoured to be your independent candidate for Leicester South. My roots run deep in this city, having been raised, educated, and now working here. Leicester South isn’t just a place where I conduct business; it’s my heart , home, and commitment. 

For over 15 years, I have been privileged to serve our community through my award-winning optical practice and my community work.  This has given me a unique perspective on our city’s challenges and opportunities. I have witnessed firsthand the struggles of hard-working individuals and families as they try to make ends meet in the face of a rising cost of living. I have seen the strain on our NHS as it copes with increasing demand and limited resources. I have watched local businesses, our economy’s backbone, struggle to survive in an increasingly competitive market. I have seen the impact of neglect on our environment as we fail to take the necessary steps to protect and preserve it for future generations. But I also believe that Leicester South is a city of immense potential. We are a diverse and vibrant community, rich in culture and history. We have a strong sense of community spirit and a willingness to work together to overcome challenges. I believe that by harnessing these strengths and working together, we can build a brighter future for our city.

As your representative, I am committed to putting the needs of Leicester South first. I will not be beholden to party politics or special interests. My loyalty lies with you, the people of Leicester South. I will listen to your concerns, advocate for your needs, and work tirelessly to ensure that our city is a place where everyone has the opportunity to thrive. I am passionate about creating a fairer, more inclusive, and prosperous Leicester South. I believe that by working together, we can make this vision a reality. I am excited to embark on this journey with you, and I am confident that together, we can build a brighter future for Leicester South.

Please do not hesitate to contact me to share your concerns, ideas, or suggestions. I am here to listen, and I am here to serve you. Thank you for being so supportive, and I look forward to working with you to make Leicester South an even better place to live, work, and raise a family.

Shockat Adam

Since being elected in 2011 I've worked hard with you to improve our community and give a better future to our children and grandchildren.

Every week I stand up for people in Leicester and Westminster. I'm always out and about across Leicester helping thousands of local people with issues and problems.

I'm always on your side and always fighting your corner.

CRAIG HARWOOD: Leicester South’s Champion for Change - How can I help?

I am Craig Harwood, proud to stand as your Reform Party candidate for Leicester. An immigrant to the UK and a Leicestershire resident since 2001 - I‘ve called Braunstone Town and now, with my cherished family, Burbage, home.

My journey with the Reform party comes from my deep-rooted concern for the UK’s future and its current economic trajectory. Our political landscape is plagued by a self-serving elite who continue to neglect the welfare of the majority. As a parent I see a pivotal choice for this country: perpetual decline under the existing parties, or champion change with Reform UK.

I advocate for:

Economic Empowerment

Increasing the tax-free personal allowance to £20 000 Abolishing energy tax on household bills - saving £500 per household. NHS Transformation

Ending NHS Waiting lists by using independent healthcare providers. More medical professionals - Lifting the cap on the number of UK medical students. Affordable Energy

Scrap Nett Zero  End £10 Billion renewal subsidies for old renewable energy infrastructure Fast track North Sea Gas and oil permits and issue Shale Gas licenses to encourage price stability and security of supply.  Let’s make the next 4 years be better than the last 4 years. Together, let’s move forward to a future of higher wages, lower taxes and real growth. This is our contract with you. Vote Crag Harwood for real representation.

I have served the community for many years and understand its needs through casework as a local councillor and supporting an MP. I have been a carer, a governor of both Sparkenhoe and Madani Schools and worked in policy to advocate for the marginalised. I live in Leicester South with my husband and children. So what matters to Leicester South matters to me.
https://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/news/leicester-news/liberal-democrat-candidate-leicester-seat-9083309

Public Services in the United Kingdom are under-funded and suffering.

The Big Two Parties have run out of energy and ideas on policing and protecting people’s security, failing to offer any different solutions.

The Big Two parties are tired and stale, they have abandoned local communities and are only interested with what happens in Westminster. That is why I am putting myself forward as the Green Party Candidate for Leicester, Leicestershire and Rutland’s Police & Crime Commissioner.

If elected I will

Provide resources to keep everyone safe from harm — supporting the people who deal with crime on a daily basis.   Invest in services for victims of crime, particularly support for those suffering Domestic Abuse. Help to build strong communities by providing young people with the services to achieve their full potential and protect them from crime. The Green Party believes in well-funded public services, not a competition between the Big Two parties to see who can chase headlines while failing to invest in public safety.

When elected at a local, regional or national level, Greens have a track record of working hard for their communities and standing up for the most vulnerable.  I look forward to continuing this tradition if elected at May’s Police Commissioner election. 

If you want to change the way things are done and stand up for public service policing, please Vote Green for Police & Crime Commissioner on 2nd May.

 

This statement has been prepared by Patrick Kitterick, 7 Guthlaxton Avenue, Leicester on behalf of Aasiya Bora

favourite_biscuit: "I'm more into savoury snacks. Currently popcorn."
statement_to_voters:
I love our city and it has been the honour of my life to serve as the MP for Leicester West. From backing our schools and hospitals to campaigning for decent jobs, homes and more police, I've always put local people first.



Every week people tell me about the struggles they face to pay the bills, get to work or even see their GP. It doesn't have to be this way. Labour has a plan to get our city and country growing again. We'll work with businesses to create good jobs that pay a decent wage, invest in our local NHS and schools, and recruit more police to make communities safe.



We need a Labour government to make the changes our city desperately needs and that is why I am again standing as the Labour candidate for Leicester West.

Stuart, like many in Wigan, was born in Billinge Hospital. He grew up with his parents, his older brother and sister not far from Wigan infirmary. He went to Mab's Cross Primary and later Deanery secondary school. It was in this early stage of his adult life that the importance of politics became apparent. Living in Wigan his entire life, Stuart can strongly empathise with its residents. During his campaign for local council, Stuart spoke to many of the residents who drew strong connection with him for the needs of the town. Today, Stuart continues to work with the residents and helping them when necessary with whatever concerns they have and continues to build strong support for himself and the Liberal Democrats.

Outside of his political aspirations, Stuart is an expert in the I.T. profession working in various business sectors, he specialises in IT forensics, compliance and cyber security. He received his first-class BSc from Manchester Metropolitan University in 2013 before starting his professional career.

When Stuart is not working hard for the community he can often be found in his home workshop, where during his free time he works on wood crafting. Stuart has a special appreciation for the outdoors and wild life and often brings his hobbies together building homes for animals.

"I stood for the District and Town Councils two years ago because I was sick and tired of people talking down our town.

"As a dad raising two young children in Newhaven, I thought that our town deserved better than being used as a dumping ground for the Tories. So instead of just complaining about it, I put myself forward and was lucky enough to be elected. It is understandable that people are cynical though.

"have dedicated myself to being a loud voice for our town and I’ve been really grateful to those people who have been in touch to say they’ve noticed! We are attracting funding for new projects in the town and starting to see a real buzz.

"There are still some mountains to climb. We have our disastrous ring road and related traffic congestion. We need to get the sandy West Beach reopened. And we need to do much better at supporting local young people with skills and training.

"I hope that you’ll support me to take on these challenges and continue to bang the drum for Newhaven."

James's record of action:
Led the campaign to get our ring road resurfaced. Work is planned to start in April.
Free parking to support our town centre shops and businesses.
Changing the way people think about our town and speaking up for our community.
Secured funding to finally bring the former UTC building back into use.

I am delighted to be given the chance to set out Labour's positive vision for the country to voters in Newhaven, Seaford, Polegate, Lewes and the villages that make up our constituency.



As Chair of the Lewes Area Labour Party branch, I understand the challenges facing local people, so it is a privilege to represent the Labour Party in the area in which I live, where my partner is from, and the place that I call home.



I know how much people are suffering right now with the cost of living because I have personal experience of what it is like to grow up in poverty, being afraid to leave the house, because of crime. In my day job as a Trade Union Officer, supporting key workers such as NHS staff, I see how our public services are at breaking point. After 14 years of Conservative and Lib Dems in Government, the economy is faltering and nothing works.



I believe most people want to feel safe and secure in their home and in their neighborhood, in good quality housing, with public services that work, with opportunities for them and their family, not having to worry how they will pay the bills.



That is why my top priorities will be the cost of living, giving young people the opportunities they deserve, laying the foundations for a stronger, greener economy, and fixing the NHS.

I've lived in Lewisham for over 20 years with my husband and two children, who attend local schools.

My parents came to Lewisham as part of the Windrush generation. We lived in a council home which we valued hugely. After 8 years as a local councillor, I've been proud to represent our community in Parliament since June 2018. I will continue to be your local champion, tackling the issues that matter to you.

It has been a huge privilege to serve as MP for Lewisham Deptford (which becomes Lewisham North at the general election) since 2015. I have lived in the constituency for over 20 years, and it is a joy to represent the people and places I have got to know in that time.



"For me, politics has always been local. Prior to being elected to Parliament, I served as a local councillor in Brockley ward and was chair of the Lewisham Council Labour group. I also worked for a trade union for 13 years and during my time there led campaigns against low pay, the exploitation of agency workers and the use of zero-hour contracts.



"My priority is to give my constituents a voice in Westminster, whether that's by fighting for decent housing, defending our NHS, lobbying for school funding, or protecting our environment. I have also campaigned for youth violence to be treated as a public health issue and in doing so set up the cross-party Youth Violence Commission.



"I have held several front bench roles, including almost four years spent as a whip and a stint as Shadow Minister for Civil Society. In April 2020 I was appointed Shadow Minister for Disabled People and I remain in that role today. I am incredibly proud of what I have achieved so far and look forward to hopefully continuing that work in government

Are you sick of seeing the rich get richer while the rest of us struggle to make ends meet? Are you tired of mainstream political parties turning a blind eye to war, injustice and the decline of working people’s quality of life and public services? 

As a proud resident of Deptford, I have experienced firsthand the challenges facing the people of our constituency. I have fought to organise better conditions for workplaces, joined actions to resist deportations and evictions and campaigned in solidarity with Palestine. As your candidate for Lewisham North, I want to stand with you in order to fight for a better quality of life, defend our communities and stand up for what is right. 

Although I am standing in this election to be your voice, I believe that we must campaign for the needs and aspirations of working people every day. I believe that where people get organised and fight, we can win. I am proud to be a member of the local campaigning Communist Party in Lewisham. Vote for me, your Communist candidate, and send a message to mainstream politicians that we need radical change today!

I have made the South East of London my home, after moving to the city nearly five years ago. I have studied in Deptford, marched in Lewisham, and have lived across a number of boroughs in the region. Lewisham and Dulwich are two areas full of life and community, and I am tired of seeing this being eroded by Westminster politics. There are many fundamental issues in this country, making life extremely hard for many people, and I want to offer an alternative for people to vote for against the current lacklustre main parties. I will always stand for economic, social, and climate justice for anyone who calls the constituency their home.

Ellie Reeves is MP for Lewisham West and Penge, having been first elected in 2017. Before entering Parliament she was an employment rights lawyer for over a decade. She also served on Labour's National Executive Committee for 10 years and was vice-chair of the London Labour Party. In 2020 she was appointed Shadow Solicitor General, in December 2021 was promoted to Shadow Justice Minister, and is now Deputy National Campaign Coordinator.

My priorities as mayor will be:

Scrap the Mayoral system which puts all the decision making in the hands of one person. Give back power to the local councillors who are more approachable.

Young people must be the priority – the council needs to run its own apprenticeship schemes for school leavers and employ staff directly to run council services – stop the contracting out to developers and multi-national corporations: Local jobs for local people. More resources for youth clubs to ensure that youngsters have positive experiences rather than being alienated and drifting into drugs, alcohol, gangs and violence.

The council should open under-5s playgroups which benefit the toddlers and, importantly, the parents, who learn good parenting skills from each other and are less isolated.

Climate Change: Take effective measures to combat climate change by making insulation of our homes a priority, cutting rising energy bills AND saving the planet. Hackney’s target of becoming carbon neutral by 2040 is way behind other London boroughs such as Lewisham. Blocking roads in Low Traffic Neighbourhoods just increases pollution elsewhere.

I am honoured to have this opportunity to introduce myself as the Prospective Parliamentary Candidate for Reform UK in the constituency of Lichfield.

I am originally from the Ashby de la Zouch area and I started my career at East Midlands Airport as a cargo loader at the age of 17. I moved on to senior management positions within aviation related organisations based in the Middle East before becoming self-employed as an aviation safety consultant based in Bahrain.  During this time, I gained a PG Diploma in Training and Development and an MSc in Human Resource Development and Performance Management from the University of Leicester.

I have worked extensively throughout the Middle East, Africa and Asia which has given me a unique insight into the different approaches to governance in various cultures. In 2017 I was recognised as a Fellow of the Royal Aeronautical Society due to my contributions to global aviation safety. This experience, in a highly regulated industry, has given me the skills needed when challenged by red tape bureaucracy. Contributing to public safety across a range of cultures has required tact and diplomacy and high levels of integrity. These are attributes that I endeavour to apply to everything that I do.

In 2019 I returned to the UK to be closer to my family but because of extraordinarily high house prices I decided to live on a narrowboat. I have been moored in Barton Marina ever since however I can often be found moored in Alrewas and Fradley enjoying nature as well as visiting local canal side hostelries.

During the covid pandemic my small business was not able to trade fully and I found it a struggle to make ends meet. Because of this, I know how difficult our day to day life can be especially during the cost of living crisis. The current political situation has resulted in many of us living on the edge like this every day but it shouldn’t have to be this way.

It seems that the main political parties have moved away from that which they traditionally stand for, especially the Conservative Party. By aiming to please everyone it is obvious they are pleasing no one. This has given me the motivation and desire to give my time to the people of the Lichfield constituency in the hope that we can work together in improving our quality of life and ensuring a more positive future.

If you would like to support me and get involved, or simply want to share your opinions on how Reform UK could help you, please contact me by email or through the Reform UK – Lichfield Facebook Page.

As a single mother of four and a former nurse, Heather wants to bring a different perspective to the city council. She took a career break to raise her children and be a carer to her son, who has special needs, and after becoming involved in the Green party in 2017, she is now ready to step into politics.

Since August, she has been actively campaigning for the local community in Gorse Hill, which has included running litter picks and helping local residents get their issues sorted. She also started a petition to repair the poor pavements in the ward, which she presented to Worcestershire County Council in February.

It is an honour to again be selected as the Labour party candidate for Lichfield constituency. Lichfield has been my home since before I learned to call a place home. I have had the absolute privilege over the last 33 years to learn in our local schools, shop on our local high streets and call many of our neighbours lifelong friends.

We are blessed to live in such a beautiful and historic part of our country, with stunning natural environments in places like Chasewater, Admaston, and along the Trent; with amazing architecture in the historic centre of Lichfield and in many of our villages; with the amazing people and communities that call Lichfield, Burntwood and our villages home, and who truly make our constituency all that it is.

Over the last 14 years, though, we have all seen our local area be let down by successive Conservative governments. The closure of local doctors’ surgeries, police stations and community venues; the lack of investment in our schools and our economy; the absence of any action on sewage spills in our waterways; a total failure to respect and support our high streets; and the worst cost of living crisis in living memory.

But it doesn’t have to be this way, we can rebuild and renew the infrastructure we rely on and the bonds between our community. That’s why I’m proud to be standing on a Labour Party platform offering a decade of national renewal, and for a mission led government that will change Britain for the better.

Together, on 4th July, we can turn a page on the inaction, sleaze and crisis of the last decade and half, we can vote for change which will get the NHS back on its feet, support our high streets and properly value our natural environment. On 4th July we will all have the power to vote for change and for a brighter, more hopeful future.

I have worked consistently for the Communities of Lincoln and surrounding towns and villages since 2000 as a candidate and town and parish councillor, as a Liberal Democrat, Independent and now Liberal Party Councillor.  I chose to change from the Liberal Democrats to the Liberal Party for the reasons given below:

  Dear Elector ,   In April 2019 I formally left the Liberal Democrats and explained the   reasons for resigning:-      1. The party stance on   Brexit and unwillingness to recognise and provide a platform   for liberal leavers.     2. The   appalling internal communications emails which effectively   make it almost impossible   for activists and members to directly contact   officers.    3. The lack of promotion   of Town and Parish Councillors on an equal basis with other   member politicians.    4. The lack of new selection procedures to abolish central approval lists and the drafting in of candidates nationwide.(e.g  like you did  in Hazel Grove and other constituencies)    5. Deliberate obstruction  of electoral pacts with Liberals.    7. Complete  lack of public speaking out about the costs and political  intentions of the EU and therefore miss informing young  people of the dangers in the EU as opposed to the benefits  and potentially surrendering constitutional independence and  their future freedom and human rights in order to keep  MEP's, EU appointments and party funding.    Consequently, I  resigned my Liberal Democrat membership very sadly having  worked with officers and MP's since the time of Richard  Wainwright MP of Colne Valley....a great Liberal and am  consequently joining The Liberal Party as a Councillor and now  Parliamentary Candidate.    I very deeply regretted this but could no longer be identified with a party which so wilfully works against the express will of the people in a referendum it promoted and whose outcome it promised to observe 

I hope the above gives some useful information to those reading this site and is the same as printed in my local election material as is the personal information below.  You will also find me on YouTube at the time of the referendum on the EU membership and on the 'Centre' website formerly Liberal Leave.

Charles Shaw  (from my local town and parish leaflet) Charles Shaw has worked hard as a community activist and as local councillor for the last eight years and despite having been a Liberal Democrat spoke out in support of the Vote Leave Campaign and was the Vote Leave coordinator for the Lincoln area and has continued to speak out against the badly managed EU exit.  He campaigns often and speaks on the media regularly. Charles is a family man who equally speaks out about the total disregard for the traditions of our local communities in favour of bland government which is more concerned with politically correct processes than really helping.  As an environmentalist, he does not want our children to be part of ‘The Waste generation’ and believes happy families come from young people being shown how to manage for themselves and be given opportunities to grow as well as conform.   As chair of One East Midlands and of Lincolnshire Council for Voluntary Youth Services he leads the charge for better support for the voluntary sector which contributes so much to our community and upon which many depend. If you would like to talk to Charles about the current state of local government or politics or just give a hand in future campaigns please email electionmessage@outlook.com or telephone 07760 843910 or write to any of the addresses featured in this leaflet. Engagement in Politics is not just about the current General Election and Charles Shaw is keen to encourage more people to stand for local town, parish, district and county councils if you could like to do so yourself or are just thinking about it and would like to have an informal chat on the subject please do contact Charles Shaw who will be happy to help without obligation.

Charles Shaw (from my general election and next leaflets) Charles Shaw is a highly respected youth and community worker both locally and nationally with an extensive career covering business, local government and the Voluntary Sector. 

Experienced on Local Councils from Skellingthorpe to Bardney and a former elected member of a Drainage Board he is well aware of local community and environmental issues. Charles has worked extensively cross-party to gain improvements and support for the Community and Voluntary Sector and is the current chair of regional infrastructure support body 'One East Midlands',  Trained in Education, Youth and Community Work, Corporate Secretaryship and Insurance, he serves as Chair of The National Network of Councils for Voluntary Youth Services, is Academic Chair of The Society of Teachers in Business Education lecturing part-time and a Trustee of the National Association of Boys and Girls Clubs. Charles Shaw is a ward resident and is married with grown up children. Experienced as a  Councillor and agent and staunchly against centralised control of local government, Charles believes Lincoln City should be a unitary authority working with but free of county domination.  Married (to Daphne) with three grown up children he is well aware of the issues facing families today. As Vote Leave co-ordinator for Lincoln, Sleaford and North Hykeham he successfully co-ordinated all-party effort to achieve a fantastic result in Central Lincolnshire whilst maintaining a friendly relationship across remain and leave activists and believes working together in a co-operative yet challenging way brings results. As a former Youth and Community officer with a Metropolitan Council for Racial Equality, he recognises the demographic changes that have taken place in Lincoln over the last decade and as Chair of the Centre for Reconciliation works promoting Community Cohesion and Inter-faith understanding across the County and beyond. As a councillor and politician he feels it is important to be the 'imp' who gets things done! Charles can be contacted direct during elections on 07760 843910

Co-founder of LCR Pride Foundation, John Hyland is the Lib Dem hopeful in Liverpool Garston. Growing up in Wavertree, Hyland cares deeply about the city and wants to give residents in Garston a fresh alternative to both Labour and the Conservatives. He has deep ties to lots of local charities and community organisations - he is a former co-chair of Liverpool Pride, and has recently been working closely with Sahir House. Hyland was a Councillor in Northern Ireland for the Alliance Party but now is back in his home city standing up for the people Labour has taken for granted.

Waterfront Councillor Rebecca Turner is challenging the City Centre seat of Liverpool Riverside. Cllr Turner has made a big splash as the youngest councillor on the City Council speaking out on sewage dumping in the River Mersey, as well as increased and improved public transport along Liverpool’s waterfront. As a scientist and young female councillor, Turner is always looking to break the glass ceiling and empower women.

Sean Cadwallader is contesting the Liverpool Walton seat. Originally from Wavertree, Cadwallader has worked with Alder Hey CAMHS in the past to raise awareness of mental health issues in Liverpool. He is another young face on the ballot paper for the Lib Dems, and, like the overwhelming majority of people his age, he is sick of the Conservative Government and wants to see a change. Cadwallader doesn’t see Starmer’s Labour as a safe pair of hands but instead thinks that the Lib Dems will work hardest for residents in Walton.

Cllr Billy Lake lives in the heart of the new Tuebrook Larkhill Ward

He has campaigned to secure the renovation of Peter Lloyd Sport Centre,  On the Planning Committee has contested the encroachment of HMO's Working with Cllr Steve Radford he led the campaign to remove the West Derby Road cycle lane scheme which caused massive traffic congestion, aggravated air pollution and undermined the shopping area

As Chair of the Tuebrook Hope Group he has led the renovation of Christ Church to become a Youth Hub whilst retaining the historic chapel

Mossley Hill Councillor Rob McAllister-Bell is standing for the newly revised Liverpool Wavertree constituency.  Since being elected in 2021, Cllr McAllister-Bell has been very vocal in the Council Chamber, recently sharing a personal account of his mother’s homelessness in her youth during a debate about the same issue. He has been robust in his debate with the Labour Party and is not afraid to stand up against them and call out their shortcomings. If elected as the new MP for Wavertree, McAllister-Bell pledges to work hard all year round for residents to make sure they aren’t overlooked.

Born and bred in West Derby, Kayleigh Halpin is Liverpool through and through. She's currently finishing her undergraduate degree in Maths from the University of Liverpool and regularly gives back to her community. She is a volunteer maths tutor at a local school and does widening participation work with the university promoting maths as a higher education option for disadvantaged students. Halpin made her electoral debut in the Fazakerley East By-Election standing up for residents against a complacent Labour administration in the Town Hall. She’s ready to take on Labour and says it’s time that people in West Derby have visible local MP standing up for them.

I have served the previous Tuebrook and Newsham Park Ward and the Tuebrook and Stoneycroft ward for over 42 years as a Liberal Party Councillor and Local  resident

I have week in week out given dedicated service to the every days problems of our communities.

We have also been at the forefront challenging the abuse of power of Councillors and Council officers alike

I am proud of the community initiatives we have led ,bringing in extra funds to support food hamper schemes, youth activities, community centre renovations

We will always put the city and community first above petty party politics

W

When I was first elected in 2015 I could never have predicted four years on, amidst chaos and uncertainty, we would be heading for the polls for our third General Election. 

I don’t think many people could, these are extraordinary times.  

It has been the privilege of my life to represent my hometown of Livingston since 2015 and I am proud of the record I stand on, one of standing up for equality, against injustice and the brutal Tory welfare cuts that have hit the poorest in my constituency and across Scotland hardest. 

In this time amongst many other things I have:

Campaigned successfully to keep local libraries open when the West Lothian         council Labour and Conservative administration tried to close them

Set up a community hub with local volunteers to ensure no Kaiam workers went     without support when they lost their jobs just before Christmas.

Launched the All Party Parliamentary Group on Deaths Abroad and Consular Services following the suspicious deaths of constituents Julie Pearson and Kirsty Maxwell delivered a comprehensive report that will seek to overhaul the way families are properly supported.

Successfully lobbied the UK Government to create an Independent Aviation Noise Authority (IANA) and set up a local noise board so that local communities affected by aviation noise can be heard and involved in decisions.

Run two Marathons, completed the KiltWalk and trekked 120km to raise money for local charities (Jak’s Den, the Michelle Henderson Cervical Trust and West Lothian Drug and Alcohol Project.)

I hope that I have proven to my constituents that I am a strong voice for the people of Livingston, but what I know is that in this campaign and in these unprecedented times we can’t afford to take a single vote for granted.

Born and brought up in Livingston, Cameron went to school and college in the town. He has previously stood as a candidate in the 2019 General Election and the Livingston South By-Election last year. Livingston does not have any young councillors, at the age of 21, Cameron wants to break the barrier and give the young people of Livingston South a voice on the council.

He currently works for Green Co-Leader and MSP Lorna Slater in the Scottish Parliament as her Parliamentary Assistant. In this role Cameron regularly communicates with West Lothian Council as well as representatives from the Scottish Government. He has helped locals with a variety of issues such as planning cases and light pollution.

Cameron strongly believes that everyone should have access to a safe, warm and affordable home and is keen to push West Lothian further to achieve this. The introduction of an empty homes strategy to bring disused and abandoned properties back into use would be one of his main goals if elected in May.

He also wants a cleaner Livingston which is why he campaigned over the past few years for a cleaner River Almond, he supported the application for a bathing waters status and has been in conversation with stakeholders on the Greens vision for the river.

People right across Livingston constituency are hopeful for the future. Of course we are, it's a wonderful place to live and bring up a family. But we need an MP and government that's on our side.



After well over a decade of the SNP and Tory governments, people across Livingston constituency are asking: have our lives got better?



It's time for a fresh start.



We need a government that is focussed on what matters to you and your family: properly funding our NHS and schools, building an economy that works for working people, getting police back on our streets, and helping families with the cost-of-living crisis. I will stand up for you - and be an MP who works tirelessly to make sure everyone, no matter their background, can thrive.



Vote Labour for the change Scotland needs.

party_name: Plaid Cymru - The Party of Wales

statement_to_voters:
I have lived in the centre of Swansea for many years working as a contracts and facilities manager both within the NHS & Ministry of defence.  My job was to keep the lights on and people safe.  From supplying the bedlinen, food and medical gasses to building brand new hospital wings and housing for our Armed Forces. My greatest achievements have been to rescue five people from the wreckage of a burning aircraft, house troops for the Olympic Games in 2012 and set up The Voice of Wales and of course Volunteering in support of the Army, building beds and decontaminating Ambulance’s during the pandemic.

Why have I stood  Unlike the other Candidate I have a proven track record of volunteering and helping out in the community, having just finished decontaminating Ambulances during the pandemic in support of the Army and prior to that building beds at the Dragon Heart Field Hospital. I am Chairman of Henllys Community Group and the Regional Co Ordinator for No. 13 (South Wales) Group Royal Observer Corps Association.   

 Labour have not only controlled the Council for many years but returned Councillors for Castle Ward year after year. The reward for such loyalty – The highest crime area in the Country – Swansea dubbed ‘Brown Town’ due to the amount of Heroin available on her streets – Aggressive begging from spaced out vagabonds who brawl and steal without let or hindrance Prostitutes and drug dealers openly plying there trade and the Council and South Wales Police believe ‘education’ is the path not prosecution just like the 21 girls who, (even in lockdown) where sexually assaulted and had genital mutilation inflicted upon their person because the ‘Partnership working’ doesn’t involve stopping this barbaric practice for fear I believe of being labelled ‘racist’. An outside Wales ‘Independent Audit’ of the Council needs to take place because to many Contracts are being given to too few firms and for a Contractors to go bust mid contract – like on the Kingsway development scheme I feel shows a level of ineptitude either by the Contracts department or the Council in general – I suspect both. 

What do you think the key issues are in your ward? The Council listening skills need to be improved for a start. We all saw the spectacle of Cllr Rob Stewart telling disabled people that is they didn’t like where they lived in Wind Street – to Move. People in specialist wheelchairs and other disabilities who have lived in Henllys for many years being told to ‘jog on’! 

Recovery from the Pandemic, must be a priority, with the needs of Business and Industry, understood and met. Small businesses and the fishermen have suffered the most. 

The Never-ending roadworks around the whole of Swansea are a joke yet Roads remain poor!  Swansea needs to get moving again and with herd immunity which we are told we now have should Guarantee ‘NO MORE LOCKDOWNS’. The terror of the traffic Warden scaring people out of shopping in Swansea hits businesses badly. People with Blue Badges should be allowed to park for free for three hours and people popping into shops for 1 hour.  All City Centre businesses waved business rates and market stallholders reduced rents. All paid from by cutting the spurious ‘voluntary groups – labours little helpers) funding and projects like the Taco Bridge which once completed will burden the Council Tax payers for years.  Real jobs with Trade Apprenticeships not row after row of coffee shops, fast food ,betting offices and charity shops. 

The unacceptable level of people high on drugs fighting and petty crime makes Castle Ward feel unsafe. This is simply Inexcusable. We need every part of the City to feel and to be safe.

Stopping the Council jumping on every bandwagon that comes along in particular BLM and Extinction Rebellion. It’s clear the Council through creative accounting will meet the above targets but the Child labour Costs are immeasurable as the electric vehicles are made from minerals mined by child slavery. 

What difference do you think you could make? I won’t be taking my constituents for granted. I will be keeping the Councils feet to the fire. We now have an Army of Local Government Officers yet we cannot keep Swansea tidy, safe or even pothole free. Swansea is a shadow of herself if anyone cares to look at the photographs of the 1950 and 60’s. Swansea was a place to come to. Now with Swansea as a City of Sanctuary and the swathes of immigrants loafing around the City Centre makes people feel unsafe and not a place to travel to as a holiday destination.  

Voice Of Wales – The Station for the Nation Co-founder of the Voice of Wales a internet and media channel. We are your 'go-to' place for real news ignored, suppressed and neglected by the mainstream media. Covering news which impacts the lives of our fellow countrymen and women both foreign and domestic. We are not 'just another news site', we proudly bring the voice of the silent majority to life. http://www.voiceofwales.com

Air Crash Rescue Hero A HOLIDAYMAKER from Manchester was hailed a hero after rescuing passengers from a light aircraft when it crash-landed just yards away from him on a beach in South Africa. http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/greater-manchester-news/air-crash-hero-saves-6-1171644

Host Military Personnel - Olympic Games 2012 Over thousand-Armed Forces personnel were dispatched to Feltham DGC. I had to prepare the base – act as liaison for facilities management issues and ensure that both the normal business of the site continued. During the Olympic Games the site received two royal visits and Ministerial visits to thank us for our hard work.  https://www.mylondon.news/sport/other-sport/feltham-home-olympic-military-security-5977028

Volunteering in support of the British Army As part of the RE:ACT Disaster Response group, Stan says he’s been helping the Welsh Ambulance Service decontaminate ambulances at Singleton Hospital – helping ensure a speedy turnaround of Ambulances which would otherwise have been off the road for several days. The group of volunteers worked 12 hour shifts, 7 days a week. https://swanseabaynews.com/2021/04/07/swansea-ukip-candidate-comes-clean-revealing-lockdown-volunteering-decontaminating-ambulances/

Royal Observer Corps Association gives the opportunity to continue meeting with colleagues and to maintain the comradeship, spirit and ethos of the Corps into the future. This year members have helped with Operation Re:ACT and in support of the British Army helped build Hospital Beds at the Dragon Heart Field Hospital in Cardiff and Ambulance decontamination at Singleton Hospital in 2020.  https://www.rocatwentytwelve.org/uploads/1/2/9/1/12917554/volunteers_again_13_group.pdf

My family has lived in East Lothian for generations. I was born on a hill sheep farm in the Highlands and have lived in Dunbar for nearly 6 years with my wife and our two kids, who go to local schools. I coach and referee at Dunbar mini rugby and volunteer in projects working for children in the care system. I want to be your MP because I deeply care about our community and believe in taking real action to make our lives better.

For most of the last fifteen years, I’ve been the CEO of Who Cares? Scotland. Where I fought for children in care who have been dealt the worst hand. Under my leadership we didn’t just talk about change—we made it happen. We showed that with care and action, we can transform lives. I’ve spent my life making a difference, from promoting democracy in Lithuania to tackling poverty in India and Ghana and building peace across former-Yugoslavia.

I’ve seen firsthand what happens when people fall through the cracks through no fault of their own—it’s unnecessary and unacceptable.

I want to be your MP, as I’ve seen too many politicians make empty promises, but they mostly get in the way instead of helping us thrive. The Liberal Democrats are different. We are fundamentally liberal. We respect people and will empower you to make a difference in your lives.

We have a local growing economy, but successive governments just interfere and make it harder for our businesses to thrive. We need policies that support growth without getting in the way. Small businesses are the backbone of our community, and they need fewer obstacles and more support.

Local green energy successes like the Berwick Bank wind farm should do more to benefit the local communities directly.

Schools should have the freedom to innovate and help our children succeed. Our healthcare system must be accessible and local, especially for end-of-life care. It’s unacceptable that community hospitals in Dunbar and North Berwick are closing, and this must be urgently addressed.

As your MP, I will deliver results. I’ve got a proven track record. I’ve delivered progressive solutions on budget and on time, showing that experience and passion can make a real difference.

It’s time we had quality people in the House of Commons, people who are competent and effective. I care about East Lothian and its people. I care about East Lothian’s stunning environment. I care about this constituency and will represent you faithfully. Let’s take action together.

favourite_biscuit: Vegan custard creams from the Harbour cafe at Fisherrow!
statement_to_voters: I’m standing because the cost of living crisis is fundamentally a cost of fossil fuel crisis, and it will only get worse the longer we delay on climate action. East Lothian is vulnerable to climate change, especially in terms of flooding, erosion, and agricultural production. But we are also uniquely placed to lead on the renewables revolution that will help to solve these problems. Dunbar’s Viridor plant wastes more than enough heat to warm all the homes in East Lothian, yet many residents suffer from fuel poverty. Meanwhile, battery storage applications are driven by speculative business interests rather than a strategy based on the common good. We must move beyond this outdated economic system that allows the rich to accrue more profits while driving inequality and a ravaged planet. A vote for the Scottish Greens will ensure we hand on a fairer society and a safer climate to the next generation.

Despite today's difficulties, I am hopeful and determined. Hopeful about the prosperous, greener future we can build. Determined to help deliver it.



I've devoted my life to making families better off. That's why I became an Economist, taught in schools, and was a trade union rep.



I became an Economist so I could make families more prosperous. I learnt my trade in the Treasury and gained a PhD. In my current day job at a think tank, I work on policies that will ensure every person in this country has enough money to thrive, public services they can rely on, and a Green New Deal that will get us to Net Zero with good jobs across the country.



I also spent two years working to end poverty inside the Somaliland government, one of the poorest and most fragile nations on earth. A nation where climate change is already leading to devastating droughts and starvation. I co-wrote their National Development Plan, economic policy, and budgets to help put them on the path to prosperity.



I've also taught children in disadvantaged schools. That doubled the chances of those kids getting into good universities. And as a trade union rep, I organised my members and stopped a 33% pay cut for my low-paid colleagues.



Service and hard work can create a better future. Those are the British values my family taught me. My grandfather served in the war, my parents started a business. Those are the values that I've lived my life by.



Those values are why I'm working so hard to win this election. To serve the people of Loughborough, Shepshed, and the Villages. To work tirelessly for a better, greener future.



Let's build that better, greener future together.

“We all love this area and are proud to call it home. Sadly, like the rest of Tory broken Britain, we’ve seen the collapse in our public services. NHS waiting lists grow by the day, the roads are potholed, sewage is pumped into the rivers and sea, police are overwhelmed and prisons are so full court cases are being delayed because there is no room for the guilty to be jailed.

“Instead of governing and solving our problems, the Tories squabble between themselves and fight over who their next leader will be. Enough is enough, time for a change. Vote for change, vote Liberal Democrat on the 4th of July.”

Jonathan Slater has been selected as Labour's Parliamentary candidate for Louth and Horncastle.



Jonathan is a policy and engagement professional with over twenty years' experience of working for national, international, regional, and local organisations. For the last 3 years he has worked as the national Strategic Engagement Manager for Maximus UK, where he is responsible for a national partnership with the Recruitment and Employment Confederation, in supporting people into sustainable work.



A lifelong Hull City fan and a member of the Labour Party for nearly 30 years, Jonathan also has experience of working for the community as a local councillor, supporting residents with their housing needs, particularly through the pandemic and following cost of living crisis.



Speaking after his selection, Jonathan Slater said;



"I'm very excited to have been selected as the Labour Parliamentary Candidate for Louth and Horncastle."



"As someone who lives in a rural village I fully appreciate the challenges that many of my constituents have in the need to be able to access high-quality employment opportunities which I will campaign for - fighting for more affordable housing which is right for the constituency with the right community infrastructure, and finally lobbying for better national and local transport links to ensure all local constituents have the ability to travel to their place of work, as well as visit and support our local high streets."



"Finally I want to highlight how our NHS been let down over the last 14 years, typified by the current MP and Secretary of State for Health, where I will highlight Labour's plans to cut the waiting lists, ensuring more in person GP appointments, and greater access to more NHS registered dentists."

I work in the voluntary sector, and was previously Political Advisor to Dame Tessa Jowell. I grew up partly in Cavenham, in Suffolk, before moving to Gorleston in Great Yarmouth, just along the coast.

I worked in a coalition of campaigners to amend the Domestic Abuse Bill which resulted in children being listed in their own right as victims of domestic abuse, and helped to convince the Government to introduce England's first ever domestic abuse code word, Ask for ANI, for victims who need to flee dangerous perpetrators.

I'm passionate about fighting for the causes I believe in. As the MP for Lowestoft, I would be a fierce advocate for change at a local and national level. We must fix our crumbling infrastructure, put Lowestoft at the heart of Labour's green industrial revolution, and tackle the cost of living crisis.

Half of all residents in our constituency are cutting back on food and energy, and Lowestoft in particular has high rates of deprivation and wards where one in four children live in poverty.

People in Lowestoft need a local champion who will fight for change in Parliament. As our Labour candidate and MP, I promise to put the needs of our community first.

Lowestoft has so much going for it and should be the jewel in the crown of the area, but years of neglect and under-investment have caused much deprivation. It does not have to be this way. My vision is of a vibrant town with thriving businesses and the arts, high employment in the engineering, environmental and tourism sectors, and a protected natural environment.

"Adam Robertson has lived in Carlton Colville ward for the past 14 years. educated at The Denes High School. Adam has since graduated from Aberystwyth University prior to his successful MA at UEA. Norwich in 2015.

Hard working, committed local campaigner Adam has been involved with several community projects including, founding the Waveney Lodgers, a disability football team. He is currently employed by a disability charity based near Norwich."

I am local and love my wonderfully diverse home town of Luton where I have lived virtually all my life. I was born in the Luton & Dunstable Hospital, I grew up in Biscot and went to Denbigh High School. I studied at Luton Sixth Form College before going to Leicester University. My first Saturday job was in Littlewoods in the Arndale (now Primark) and my first full-time job was at the TSB bank customer service centre that used to be on Cardiff Road. Later on in life, as part of my 20+ year career working in the public sector and wider civil service, I studied part-time for a Masters degree at the University of Bedfordshire in Luton.

I live in High Town with my partner Iain and, like you, I use our local services - I take the train from Luton Station, I shop locally (on High Town Road or Bury Park Sainsbury’s) and have gone to Woodland Avenue GP surgery since I was a baby! I'm involved in supporting our Luton community, as a governor at Luton Sixth Form College since 2014 and I'm a regular volunteer at Luton Foodbank.

Having spent my life in Luton, together with family and friends across the constituency, I know Luton like the back of my hand. I am a councillor on Luton Council, first elected over 8 years ago, currently representing High Town ward. I'm the Executive Member for Public Health.

I will be an MP who has real life experience, local credibility and a strong track record. And I believe it is imperative to be accountable to everyone you represent.

Since childhood I've always stood up for fairness and equality for all. This developed into a deep sense of social justice which I have held all my life. I have stood up for people's rights at work and against attacks on our pay and pensions.

We must tackle the inequalities between the very rich and the rest of us. Under Labour, our economy will work for the many. I have always advocated for democratic public ownership of key parts of our economy including our railways, energy, water and the Royal Mail. I am wholly opposed to the privatisation of our NHS and believe schools should be brought back under local authority control. We must put people before profit.

As your MP, I will stand up for the many, not the few.

As a proud resident of Luton, I am dedicated to serving our local community and our country. My commitment to politics is driven by a desire to represent the interests of the British working class at all levels.

I am standing for the Workers Party GB to be a strong voice for the people of Luton, advocating for their needs and concerns locally, nationally, and internationally.

The UK CONSERVATIVE PARTY AND LABOUR Party should never be forgiven for their complicity in the countinus genocidal war in Gaza. They have supported the genocidal regime of Israel without any justification.

We should recognise the State of Palestine immediately. As a country, we have a moral obligation to stand up for Palestinian people and call for immediate end to the war against innocent defenceless people.

British working class has been neglected by the political elites for years. It's time to change the two party system.  “Only the Workers Party will stand up for British working class and  save the future of our Union."

We have so many challenges for the working class in our great country. If elected, my priorities are:

Housing crisis High rents and shortage of affordable housing 

Support for first time buyers to enable young people to climb the housing ladder

Dealing with the issue of an Increase in knife crime in luton by dealing with the issue at ground levels through educating young people. 

A multidisciplinary approach towards dealing with issues relating to young people and finance youth clubs.

Fight anti-social behaviour  Drugs and misuse of other substances through a robust education programme as well as support and guidance for young people and families once it does become an issue 

Providing/supporting routes to ensure local jobs are for local people.

Bring more investment in Luton in high technology businesses.  Apprenticeships are difficult and simplify them into more funded youth training schemes.

The future of our country is in your hands at this election. With two old Parties rehashing tried and failed ideas and moving increasingly to the right and left. The Liberal Democrats offer a bold vision for our country, the party for business but with a conscience, creating a fair society for all. 

We are the fifth largest economy in the world yet one in five live in poverty. I’m angry that schools can’t afford to pay their teachers and are asking parents to provide essentials like toilet roll. I’m angry that our NHS faces another winter crisis and people wait in ambulances because of a lack of beds. 

We are facing a global climate emergency, and yet it has been largely ignored with mere lip service paid. We have a radical and credible plan to tackle the emergency and protect our future. Investing in Green technology will protect our planet for future generations and boost our economy locally and nationally. 

Instead of addressing these serious problems we have wasted three years arguing about Brexit. We now know that Brexit will make us poorer, damage our economy and will be bad for Macclesfield, its families and its businesses. The Liberal Democrats are the strongest Party of Remain. We believe the way to end the chaos is to stop Brexit. 

There is no simple way to get Brexit done, we face many years more of chaos, confusion and uncertainty. Uncertainty puts jobs at risk and stops us from focusing our efforts on fixing the big issues we are facing in the NHS, education and the climate.

Our people, our businesses and our country deserve better. We can build a brighter future for our country and our towns and rural communities here in Macclesfield.

Amanda is a local resident, active in green and environmental matters and in the community •    Council Election Candidate for Knutsford 2023 •    Born in Manchester, and a local resident since 2020 •    Facilitator for a Macclesfield addiction recovery group •    Student at Macclesfield College •    Volunteer Adviser for Citizens Advice 2018-2023

Whoever forms the next government will need to tackle the climate emergency: •    switching away from oil and gas, and towards renewables;  •    improving the energy performance of our housing (existing as well as new); and  •    taking effective action on climate change to protect the current generation, and those yet to come.

A Vote for the Green Party is not a wasted vote!

The larger our vote, the bigger our influence, and the stronger the chance that promises made by other candidates are met, and not avoided, once they are elected.

By voting Green you can show that you share our faith that the UK is a country of good, compassionate, talented people who can solve our problems by facing them together.

Tactical voting only works if you end up with what you want. If you want a fairer, more equal society committed to addressing the climate emergency (and keeping the NHS in public ownership) you need to VOTE GREEN.

We can do better for Macclesfield, for everyone, not just the few.

I'm proud to be from Macclesfield. My mum and her mum before her, worked in our local NHS and I went to school in Poynton. It's a great area with great people, but Macclesfield has been taken for granted by the Conservatives for too long.



Our communities are confronting immense challenges: from the cost of living crisis to decaying public services, and the issue of our time -- the climate emergency. All of us have seen the decline of our town centre and the lack of attention paid to our rural communities. Meanwhile, prices are up and living standards are down. We face record NHS waiting times in Cheshire East and schools literally crumbling while the government stands by. As we've seen with the Bollin, sewage is being pumped into our rivers at an alarming rate. And our country's reputation abroad is at rock bottom.



The next election is an opportunity we don't want to miss. After 14 years in power, the Conservatives have crashed our economy, decimated our public services, and lost people's trust. Together we have a chance to have a Labour representative in parliament for the first time ever -- an MP who works for all our communities. I've beaten the Tories in their own backyard, now I want to do the same for my hometown. I want to see an area that's no longer neglected but supported to be the best possible place to live, work and grow old.

Together we can build a brighter future for Macclesfield.

Jo is a HR and Employee Relations expert working within the Trade Union movement. She has lived in Maidenhead for over 20 years. Jo is well known across the constituency as a strong community campaigner and activist. She is particularly driven by injustice, inequality and discrimination and is a passionate advocate for education and the rights of working people.

Born in Liverpool Maureen has lived in the Maidstone for 38 years, arriving when her family were posted to 36 Engr Regt Invicta Park in 1986. A proud trade unionist Maureen is a member of UNISON was a lead negotiator at Kent County Council, she has worked in local government, NHS and private and voluntary sector in mental health services. With a family background in the armed forces Maureen is a service champion. As part of her community engagement she is a member of the organising committee for the Maidstone Mela, an Independent Custody Visitor and supports community larders in Maidstone.



Maureen is Leader of the Labour Group on Maidstone Borough Council and is committed to improving services for local residents and bringing the change that Maidstone & Malling so desperately needs.

Dave is a local businessman who has run his own building company for nearly 50 years. Elected to represent East ward of Maidstone Borough Council in 2002 he has been involved in many areas of the Council and has a particular interest in Leisure having served on the Leisure Committee and being the current Chairman of Maidstone River Festival Committee and is keen to see the Borough make more of the River in general.

He has also been a Youth Worker and is the current warden of the Howard de Walden Youth Club and is a past Chair of Maidstone Sea Cadets. Recently Dave was a popular Mayor of Maidstone. Currently he is a member of the Licensing Committee and an active campaigner to protect and improve community facilities.

Maria is a Psychology student at Lancaster University with a passion for politics and giving back to the local community.  She moved to Lancaster last year from Birmingham and has fell in love with all that the area has to offer. 

At Sixth Form, Maria was a member of the student council and was a key player in organising and staffing numerous charity fundraisers which in total raised thousands of pounds for various charities. She has also been a volunteer for the Mind charity, working in one of their charity shops helping to raise money and awareness for mental health conditions, ensuring that no one has to face mental health struggles alone, a message she hopes to push further through both the political system and through her degree.

Maria is a firm believer in the ideas and values of the Green Party and feels she would be capable of best putting these ideas of climate action and support for the local community into practise while being a voice for young people, a group so often overlooked in politics.

Simon Burwood runs to be Maldon’s Lib Dem MP Maldon’s new Liberal Democrat Parliamentary Candidate will be making health services and wellbeing a top priority in the forthcoming General Election. Lib Dem members have selected Heybridge Councillor Simon Burwood as their candidate. Simon Burwood commented, “The Conservatives have run down our local health services, as we can see from their proposed changes at St Peter’s Hospital. It is a much-loved and vital community facility, which my family has used, including when my youngest daughter was born there.   “The Conservatives lack of investment has also led to long waiting times to see GPs, even longer waiting times for ambulances, a lack of NHS dentists (with people resorting to extracting their own teeth) and an increase in mental health issues, especially in our young people. “The NHS, once the envy of the world, is now on its knees.  We need to fix it and fix it fast. It will be a huge task, but the Lib Dems are ready for it and ready to give everyone the opportunity to get on in life, wherever they start. “Maldon has also seen many new homes being built recently. Young people desperately need affordable homes but the Conservative councils and Government have failed to deliver the essential infrastructure.”

Simon Burwood has lived in Heybridge for over 25 years raising three children and playing an active part in his local community. He is currently a Heybridge Parish Councillor and has served twice as Chair of the Council.  He was elected as a Councillor on Maldon District Council for Heybridge West, in May 2023.  He is currently the President of the Heybridge Blackwater Rotary Club, which raises funds for local, national and international charities.   Simon works in adult education and manages community engagement, wellbeing, family learning and courses for adult learners with disabilities and difficulties for an Essex local authority.  In previous roles, he has managed apprenticeship programmes, working with younger people to develop their skills, knowledge, and behaviours for the workplace.    Simon believes that everyone, no matter their age, needs support to develop and achieve their potential and the Liberal Democrats’ pledge of a Skills Wallet for every adult to learn and develop is important to him. The Liberal Democrats are the second largest political party in Maldon and thus the clear challengers to the Conservatives.  A vote for Simon Burwood and the Liberal Democrats is a vote for the change that Britain desperately needs after 14 years of the Conservatives.

Parham Hashemi is proud to be your Workers Party candidate for Manchester Central. As an NHS PHARMACIST and STUDENT DOCTOR, Parham has seen firsthand the challenges our health service faces. He is deeply committed to improving the NHS, addressing the housing crisis, and advocating for the people of Gaza who are enduring unimaginable suffering.

In Manchester Central, the NHS faces significant and URGENT challenges. Hospitals across Greater Manchester are so cash-strapped each month that they are having to receive advance payments from the region’s NHS to keep services running. The region’s NHS is already under close scrutiny by national NHS bosses over its near-£180m DEFICIT, which it is under strict instructions not to allow to get worse. Several trusts are potentially RUNNING OUT OF CASH, and this financial strain is affecting the quality of care provided to our community. This situation is unacceptable and requires IMMEDIATE action.

Parham is committed to FULLY RENATIONALISING the NHS, ensuring it is funded adequately and managed efficiently. Our health service should be a beacon of hope and care, FREE from the grasp of private profiteers. He will fight to restore DECENT PAY LEVELS for our healthcare workers, ensure that patient care is NEVER COMPROMISED by budget cuts or private interests, and guarantee that NHS DENTISTRY is accessible and affordable for all. Together, we can make the NHS the PRIDE OF OUR NATION once more.

The HOUSING CRISIS in Manchester Central is a dire issue that needs immediate attention. Every person deserves a SAFE and AFFORDABLE place to call home. Parham will work tirelessly to initiate a COMPREHENSIVE PROGRAMME OF SOCIAL HOUSING, overriding unnecessary planning constraints and ensuring the right to buy or transfer sub-standard buy-to-let properties to local authorities. We must end the scandal of young people being PRICED OUT OF THEIR OWN CITY and ensure that everyone has access to DECENT, AFFORDABLE HOUSING.

The conflict in GAZA is a HUMANITARIAN CRISIS that demands our attention and action. As your representative, Parham will not shy away from SPEAKING THE TRUTH. The people of Gaza are suffering due to a BRUTAL ONSLAUGHT enabled by complicit governments, including our own. Parham stands unequivocally with the people of PALESTINE, advocating for a SINGLE STATE where all those born in PALESTINE-ISRAEL can live in PEACE with EQUAL RIGHTS. We must end the ILLEGAL OCCUPATION and support the RIGHT OF RETURN for all displaced Palestinians. Our foreign policy should reflect our values of JUSTICE and HUMAN RIGHTS.

Parham was an EX-LABOUR MEMBER who felt that Labour STOPPED REPRESENTING THE EVERYDAY PEOPLE. LABOUR NEEDS TO LEARN that it cannot TAKE VOTES FOR GRANTED. For instance, the current Labour MP for Manchester Central, Lucy Powell, abstained from voting for a ceasefire in Gaza, highlighting Labour’s failure to stand up for justice and peace.

Manchester Central deserves a representative who will FIGHT FOR THE NHS, tackle the HOUSING CRISIS, and stand up for JUSTICE IN GAZA. Parham Hashemi is that representative. Together, we can create a FAIRER, MORE COMPASSIONATE society. Vote for PARHAM HASHEMI and the WORKERS PARTY, and let’s make REAL CHANGE happen.

I'm standing as a candidate to give voters in Manchester a real alternative. The SDP is a patriotic, economically left-leaning and culturally traditional party. We recognise that the main parties are out of touch and we believe our policies will resonate with the majority of the country.

Chris moved to Manchester in 2011 and made her home in Manchester City Centre. Working in Manchester's tech sector for over a decade, Chris was elected to Manchester City Council as the city's first openly trans councillor in May 2023, and is the deputy leader of the Manchester Liberal Democrats.

In addition to her council role and local campaigning activity, she also works for a national charity as a software engineer, building websites that provide support to those in need.

Manchester Central is a safe seat for Labour, but a strong liberal challenger will mean Labour can't take Manchester for granted.

The Tories can't win in Manchester Central - the last time they did was before the second World War. The Liberal Democrats are the alternative here. In local elections, only the Liberal Democrats have beaten Labour.

Chris is campaigning for a fair deal for Manchester. A fair deal where all votes matter through proportional representation. A fair deal to eliminate poverty through a guaranteed basic income. A fair deal for housing through building more social housing, and guaranteeing people's right to live in safe, affordable homes.

PETER CLIFFORD is a Communist League leader and rail worker. As an RMT ­ member, he joins efforts to defend jobs and­ living ­ standards, and ­ organise solidarity with others.  He writes for the Militant newsweekly 

Peter says “Which class rules is the central ­ question facing workers everywhere. Break from the ­ capitalist parties: Conservative, ­ Labour, ­ LibDem, Reform, Greens, SNP.” 

Workers need our own party  A party of labour based on the unions that defends the interests of all working people- in the UK and worldwide.

Join the working-class campaign! clmanchr@gmail.com 07424-958285

Capitalist rulers’ devastation and march to war . . . It’s not who you’re against, but what you’re for.

Build, strengthen trade unions. For pay and conditions that prevent families in working class being torn apart.    Fight Jew-hatred. Defend Israel’s right to exist Back Ukraine people’s fight for independence.   Protect democratic freedoms. Oppose ‘cancel culture     Workers need to take political power – Defend example of Cuba’s socialist revolution.

I'm a community politician looking to unseat Jeff Smith - a career politician who's commitment to Kier Starmer and the party line has led him to abstain multiple times on the ceasefire vote, even after meeting with local Palestinians, multiple times. My campaign is one of hope, equality, community and humanity - demanding nothing less than the total liberation of Palestine, an end to the UK war machine (and its cost to the British tax payer) and for all residents of the Withington Constituency to live easier, healthier, happier lives.

As a long-time resident of Mansfield, I have witnessed first-hand how lives change for the better when we have a Labour MP and Government.

As a parent with children in Mansfield during the 1997-2010 Labour Government, I saw the profound impact that action by Labour in government can have on working-class families. It gave my family access to high quality education, the lowest NHS waiting times ever and a growing economy that made our lives better.

I want to inspire the people of Mansfield with a fresh message that Labour is on their side, upholds their values, and wants them to win. I have the drive and resilience to win here and the values and experience to match.

Like many areas across our country, Mansfield isn't thriving right now, but it can with a Labour MP under a new Labour Government.

As a volunteer, active member of our community and lifelong trade unionist, I have always strived to make things better. From being a school governor, volunteering for local charities that make a difference for adult social care and domestic violence, and supporting our local Credit Union. I've organised, campaigned and delivered positive change throughout my life.

Our shared values are under threat right now. We have a Tory MP who doesn't live here and doesn't act in our interests. For 14 years we have had Conservative Government that has failed us.

I am now asking for your vote, and your faith in me, to become the Labour Member of Parliament for Mansfield. Together, we can make a real difference for our community.

am what I am because of who we are. Those are the values I was brought up with by my mum and dad, growing up and going to school in a small town in the South West of England. Those are the values that make up Ubuntu, a concept I saw in action as a volunteer working with young community leaders in Zambia. And those are the values that have led me to stand for election to parliament as a Labour candidate.



I am delighted to be standing in the new constituency of Melksham and Devizes where Labour's missions will make a real difference after 14 years of this dreadful Conservative government.



I currently work as a campaigner for animal welfare, working with citizens, communities and companies to make sure that this country continues to live up to our reputation as a nation of animal lovers. I will bring that experience of campaigning, influencing as well as kindness and compassion to Melksham and Devizes.

A vote for the Green Party is a vote for more investment in the services you value, and for putting your local community at the centre of decision making.

Our candidates will listen to your needs and work hard to deliver changes that empower your community and improve everyday life. 

We believe that the challenge of tackling the climate crisis is also an opportunity to improve the lives of ordinary people. 

The Green Party will put people and planet first. Always. 

For more information on Green Party policies, see our Manifesto, here: https://campaigns.greenparty.org.uk/manifesto/

My name is Andy Konieczko, and I was recently chosen to be your Liberal Democrat prospective parliamentary candidate at the general election expected later this year.

I wanted to take this opportunity to introduce myself to you.

I was born in Leicester, grew up in Melton Mowbray and have fond memories of my time here. My parents still live in Melton, and I’m a regular visitor to the area. 

I’m also a dad of two, a school governor and a mentor for the Prince’s Trust. When I get the time, I enjoy football and travelling.

I believe in putting people first and helping them to fulfil their potential - so that we can all achieve what we want to in life. But too many people aren’t getting the opportunity to do that at the moment.  That’s why I’m convinced it’s time for change in Melton and Syston. 

I know that getting a GP and dentist appointment in our area is incredibly hard, and waiting times for ambulances are putting lives at risk.

I see first-hand the damage that the Conservatives have done to our education system and the impact that’s having on young people.

And I'm shocked that the government is letting water companies get away with dumping sewage in our precious waterways, while its policy on tackling climate change is going backwards. Labour is also wavering on its promises and not sure what to do. 

The list goes on and makes for depressing reading.

To make things worse, many of our politicians refuse to take responsibility for their mistakes.  Their arguments often become personal and nasty, and all this behaviour puts people off politics.  Unfortunately, this last parliament will be remembered for scandal rather than solutions – and the whole country is paying the price.

Melton and Syston residents deserve better.  From the conversations that we’ve been enjoying with residents over the past few months, it’s clear that people have had enough.  The next step is for you to use your vote later this year to choose an MP who’ll stand up for you and start putting things right.  

Who do you think is best placed to do that?  Is it the Conservatives - the party that created the mess we’re all facing?  Is it Labour - the party that’s admitted it can’t win in Melton and Syston so is focusing its attention elsewhere in the East Midlands?  Or is it time for fresh thinking with the Lib Dems?

Like most Britons today, the Rejoin EU Party seeks our return to full EU membership for better prosperity, enhanced security and increased personal freedoms. We seek to repair the damage Brexit has inflicted on our economy, our social cohesion and our national reputation. And we seek to pursue constitutional improvements to prevent such destructive change happening again.

I am a resident in the Vale of Belvoir.  I served in HM Diplomatic Service, the Royal Navy and the Police Special Constabulary.

Sunny, who grew up locally, is an experienced Barrister and Mediator. After he was selected, he spoke about the challenges he faces:

"During the next General Election campaign I will hold the Conservatives to account for their failings.

“Meriden and Solihull East deserves an MP who will represent the people and be a strong voice in Parliament. With your support I pledge to do just that."

party_name: Plaid Cymru - The Party of Wales

statement_to_voters:
The cost of living crisis has hit Pembrokeshire hard, with child poverty rates among the highest in Wales. As your candidate, I am pushing for quality local jobs that offer fair wages to help families get by. Additionally, I aim to urge the UK government to boost support for offshore wind and green hydrogen industries off our coastline, creating skilled sustainable employment for our region.

Residents across Pembrokeshire are frustrated with long waits to access healthcare under the Labour-led system, whether seeing a GP, finding an NHS dentist, or getting hospital treatment for serious illnesses. As your Member of Parliament, I will fight for improved accessibility to vital services, pushing for life-saving treatments like radiotherapy to be readily available for all local residents who need them.

I will also push to remove the obstacles created by the current European trade deal, ensuring future agreements uphold high standards for health, the environment and animal welfare. I am committed to preventing our local farmers and food manufacturers from facing unfair competition.

As your representative in Westminster, I will work tirelessly towards a better and fairer deal for Mid and South Pembrokeshire.

I live just outside St Davids, but I grew up in a farming family and have spent many Easters lambing and many summers doing the harvest. Professionally, I trained and practised as a barrister, specialising in healthcare, public and employment law, before leaving to work as an organiser for a grassroots trade union that helps cleaners campaign for better pay and working conditions. My values are hard work, community and caring for others. I am committed to Pembrokeshire and want to be an MP that is embedded within our local community, using my skills to fight for a kind, caring and compassionate society where everyone is valued.
