The people of Mid Bedfordshire were voiceless for years until Labour delivered change. Labour has given our towns and villages a committed, energised and visible MP who worked to earn your trust, never took a single vote for granted, and delivered locally. 

I promise to continue to be that Labour change. I will work twice as hard to deliver for you, I will put you first, and I will fight for communities that work. Communities where you can rely on local NHS services, where you can trust that new development will be in your interest, and where you aren’t in fear of rural crime, because you know that your elected representative doesn’t take your vote for granted and is committed to you.

And that’s because Bedfordshire is where I was born, grew up, and where my family rebuilt our lives after years of struggle. Through hard work, we had the opportunity to turn our lives around under a Labour government. Today, I’m a banker from a working class background with experience in the private sector financing governments, my sister is an NHS doctor, and my husband has a background in small business.

But I don’t believe in doing well for myself and forgetting about the community that got me to where I am today. That’s why I’m standing - I owe it to you to be the hardest working MP that our towns and villages have ever seen, starting immediately. I am here every single day, full time, meeting with as many of you as possible.

With Labour expected to win, it’s more important than ever that Mid Beds has an MP who belongs to the party in power and can have a meaningful voice for our towns and villages.

Join me in continuing to deliver change in and for the people of Mid Beds.

My name is Carissma Griffiths and I am a 34-year-old business woman, homeowner and millennial working full time for a construction company as a National Key Account Manager. I am not a career politician. Having watched, as all of you have, the catastrophic decline in our country, I joined the Labour Party as the party of choice to get our future back on track.



I have seen how the Tories are playing by the divide and conquer rule book, instilling an us and them culture by vilifying yesterday's heroes and praising tomorrows villains. With so many messages aimed at people's fears they purposely fail to unite us all in our common desire, which is to positively move forward.



It is time for real change.



Mid Buckinghamshire is a new and diverse constituency. It is only fair that its start begins with a change for the better.

Hello I’m Yvonne Wilding. I am a mother of 3 grown up children and have lived in Buckinghamshire since 1987 and in Great Kingshill for 13 years.  I have an amazing supportive husband Richard and we have been together for over 40 years. We play an active part in our community through church and I support local environmental groups and I am a Councillor at Hughenden Parish council. I am a scientist by training, I love nature and our beautiful Bucks countryside.  I have had a very challenging  career developing new medicines for over 40 years. I am very proud of my record for introducing new therapies but also stopping those products that either didn’t work or were unsafe. I will absolutely stand up to oppose when I believe something is wrong. When I lived in Little Chalfont there was a planning application for a massive free range chicken farm. I gave scientific evidence in court on the risks of avian viral transmission to people, which stopped the project progressing.  I also am a qualified project manager and have worked on multiple, long term, complex, global  projects. I think personal integrity and bravery are critical attributes for anyone seeking to represent their community. I also believe, If we are unhappy with what our politicians offer us, it is our responsibility to stand up and challenge it. I believe SDP offers a positive change for our country.

I have lived in Mid Cheshire for most of my adult life. It's where my children were born, and it's where I've been proud to represent as a Councillor for the last ten years during some of its most challenging times.

In Mid Cheshire, we have one in five children living in poverty. A child born in my ward in Leftwich will have a life expectancy ten years lower than one born just a couple of miles away on the other side of town.

I've chosen to dedicate my life to our community because I believe that every child should have the opportunity to reach their full potential.

To fight the pernicious idea that your background, your circumstances, who you know, where you come from might shape your life more than your talent, your creativity, or your determination.

This aspiration for the next generation is what's at stake at the next election. Get involved in my campaign, and let's win a better future - together.

I’m Mark and I’ve lived in the fabulous village of Moulton for over 20 years. Moulton is almost equal distance from our three great Salt Towns of Middlewich, Northwich and Winsford and all of them have been important to me and my family over the years. My wife taught in Middlewich, my three children have all attended Northwich schools, and I play walking football with Winsford Town.

I’ve been active working in different parts of the community; as a parish councillor; working with the police and local authority on community safety; on the liaison group for the local hazardous waste facility in the salt mine. And after being ordained in the Church of England in 2017 I was the curate at St Helens in Northwich and vicar at St Stephen’s in Moulton until September last year.

What drives me is a commitment to speaking out against injustice and inequality. It could be the water companies paying out millions in dividends while they put raw sewage in our rivers; the system that allows people to make obscene sums of money, while others have nothing; the targeting of people fleeing to our country to escape the economic and political mess that we have failed to help and address in their own countries; or the biggest issue of all, the climate emergency that will make huge parts of the world unliveable, will lead to mass migration by those who have the least and will disrupt every part of our lives.

Only The Green Party have the policies, the principles and the people to address these issues, and I’m honoured to be asking my friends and neighbours in this area, that if these are the issues that concern you,

Vote Green: Vote Mark Green

It’s a huge privilege to have the opportunity to represent the constituency where I grew up – I come from Middlesbrough and am very proud to be a Teessider.

If elected as your MP, I’ll tackle problems like the Marton Crawl, pressing our new Mayor and central Government for action to make the Ormesby Bank sliproads onto the Parkway two-way to ease pressure on Marton and Stokesley Roads.

I’ll fight for East Cleveland communities like Loftus and Lingdale that feel abandoned and ignored. I’ll champion growth, jobs and investment.

Those are my local priorities. But we also need to think about the national consequences of our vote.

My beliefs aren’t complicated. I believe in the value of hard work and taking responsibility. I believe in living within our means and not piling up debt for our children. And I believe in a strong, independent Britain which is a force for good in the world.

Those are the values of thousands of people in Middlesbrough South and East Cleveland who feel Jeremy Corbyn’s Labour Party has totally stopped speaking for them.

We should be clear: every vote for another candidate in this election is a vote for Jeremy Corbyn in Number 10, negotiating our Brexit deal and responsible for our economy and our security. That is a risk we simply must not take.

I am the only candidate here who will work with Theresa May to deliver the strong leadership we need, and a better future for our area and our country.

Source: http://www.gazettelive.co.uk/news/teesside-news/middlesbrough-south-east-cleveland-general-13120628

We need a fresh start in Middlesbrough South & East Cleveland. I'm proud to have grown up here, and serve the community as a councillor and cabinet member. I started out as a teacher here, before working in education and economic policy nationally. I've seen first-hand how our people are hurting after thirteen years of Conservative government.

That's why I'm standing to be our next MP: to get a fresh start and a better deal for our home. It's time for a change.

Candice Johnson-Cole, Prospective Parliamentary Candidate, Mid-Dorset and North Poole



"Our goals at the Mid-Dorset and North Poole (MDNP) CLP, are to help secure a Labour Party victory at the upcoming election and work with that Labour Party government and the people of Mid- Dorset and North Poole, to bring about the well overdue changes our country needs".



Born to British parents in London, Candice, a former Poole, Bournemouth and Doncaster Community Worker, Labour Party Conference Exhibition and Events Organiser and 1997 General Election On-the-Road Events Team Manager and political events consultant, made Bournemouth, Poole and then Mid-Dorset and North Poole her home over 23 years ago and has been a member of the Labour Party since 1995.



"As we await the upcoming General Election, I will be working hard for my constituency and for my neighbours, on the issues that really matter to us. Together, we can turn things around and start building toward everyone's future again. I invite everyone to join us to make this happen - we are ready!"



Candice Johnson-Cole, Prospective Parliamentary Candidate, Mid-Dorset and North Poole

Ben has lived within the BCP conurbation for nearly 30 years. Along with with his wife and three children, his family home is in Poole.

Ben works for a well-known local manufacturing company with an international reputation.

An avid sports fan and participant, he coaches the Poole RFC Juniors, plays for the Poole RFC senior men's team and has a long history of playing in the Bournemouth Saturday & Sunday football leagues. He has also completed three marathons, most recently London 2024.

As a Green Party activist, Ben has a passion for protecting the environment so that it can be passed on to our children in a better state.

Ben is a keen advocate of social justice and campaigns for our essential services like the NHS, water supply and public transport to be kept out of the hands of profiteering private enterprise.

Having studied Economics & History at university, Ben is a big advocate for the introduction of a Universal Basic Income.

Vikki is a Mortgage Broker who works around her passions for the local community, politics and her four growing children.  She first got involved in politics when she owned Molly's Cafe in Broadstone and took on the leadership of the local Chamber of Trade where, still in her 20s, she grew the organisation from 18 to 95 members, established a successful community event and lobbied for improved access for the disabled, better parking arrangements and launched business networking for local business owners.

With a history in financial services and in running a successful small business, Vikki is committed to supporting the high street and in supporting entrepreneurs.  She has employed a number of apprentices in the last ten years and is passionate about improving outcomes for young people who want to follow a wide range of careers.  As a school Governor she campaigns for improved school funding in Dorset, and is challenging the narrowing of the curriculum in secondary schools that is stripping creative and vocational subjects for many children.

As a member of Poole Council, Vikki has been involved in a number of projects including the new Anti-bullying Strategy, scrutinising and improving the standards in Children’s Centres, working to improve provision for victims of Domestic Abuse and has been a leading voice on environmental and renewable energy issues.  She has also been part of the Beachfront Strategy Team, led on banning the Badger Cull on Council land and has successfully campaigned for a number of road safety projects.

Within the community, Vikki manages the local Youth Club, works as a volunteer leader and is leading a team to take the building on as a Community Asset. She also chairs the Neighbourhood Watch, runs an environmental project Win on Waste, and founded the Broadstone Fields in Trust Association which organises an annual funday raising £000's for the community.

Our community here in Mid Dorset and North Poole deserves first-class education for our children, high quality jobs and inward investment– all the things I’ve been championing day in and day out. And I will fight for that vision by building on our successes. 

Now that the economy has finally turned a corner, we cannot go back to square one. We refuse to start over. We’ve put in the hard work during the tough times, and now it’s time to secure our future.

It is an immense privilege to be selected as the Scottish Labour candidate for Mid Dunbartonshire. I have lived in Bearsden for more than 26 years and know that the people in this constituency are desperate for change. We live in a beautiful part of the country but, to enjoy it, we need to be able to earn enough income to allow us to feed our families and heat our homes. The Labour pledges will deliver the change Mid Dunbartonshire needs and, if elected, I will work with MSPs and councillors to strengthen our communities and be a strong voice from within a Labour Government.

Key Priorities for Milngavie:  •Improving Transport links across EDC and reinstating the trains to Glasgow City every 15 min  • Enough school bus provision for all in the catchments  •Green Belt Protection  •Helping the local economy grow by supporting small businesses  •Sorting out the potholes throughout Milngavie ward •Improved communication between councillors and constituents

Mainstream politics has lost its way.

While the main parties bicker over the the Union Vs Independence debate some real leadership in Holyrood is sorely lacking.

I believe that we need to rebuild the society by rebuilding the family. We need to eliminate perverse sex education in schools which robs children of their most innocent years. We need men to man up and take responsibility for their their own life choices. This means being role models to their children. Showing their sons how to treat women properly and showing their daughters how they ought to be treated. 

Motherhood and fatherhood should be promoted as the blessing that it truly is.

The differences between man and woman should be celebrated rather than forcefully equalised by the policies or the ruling party. If a man wishes to be the sole provider and let his wife nurture and raise their children full time then this should be viewed positively.

Finally it is very important to maintain involvement in the local community. I'm very passionate about local issues myself and if anyone in the Strathkelvin and Bearsden constituency or West Scotland Region is particularly passionate about a local issue then I want to hear all about it so please do get in touch!

Thanks for reading and I do hope you can put your trust in me to represent you!

Susan Murray is the Liberal Democrat candidate for Mid Dunbartonshire. A current local councillor for Kirkintilloch East and North and Twechar, Susan is a strong, local and hardworking campaigner and has the experience that will deliver the change we need.

Too many MPs are career politicians with no understanding of life in the real world. She is a successful businesswoman who lives locally and will use here experience getting things done as an East Dunbartonshire councillor to deliver on the issues that matter most to residents.

For Susan, improving local healthcare is a personal priority. When her husband suffered a stroke, she became a carer. Her experience means Susan knows just how important it is to have good quality NHS facilities in our community, like the new Milngavie health and care centre she is campaigning for.

In Midlothian there are 2,446 children living in poverty. That's 2,446 childhoods I'm dedicating myself to changing. As an Executive Director at one of the world's biggest children's charities I lead a team of 160 to deliver award-winning campaigns and our programmes supporting families here in Scotland and across the UK.

I absolutely love my job but there's nothing I can do in it that will ever make as big a difference to our communities as Labour in government does. That's what's brought me back from community work to politics.

I was proud to work as a Downing Street adviser to Gordon Brown during the financial crisis, translating action at the G20 right down to where it made a difference, in protecting people's pensions, jobs, savings and homes.

Now I'm the chair of the advisory board for Our Scottish Future, giving a voice to everyone who wants to keep our country together but wants -- and needs -- change. I also volunteer on the boards of IPPR, The Center for Countering Digital Hate, The Labour Climate and Environment Forum, Larger Us, The Civic Power Fund and The Climate Coalition. The thing that brings all of this together is my belief that it doesn't have to be like this: that if we focus on what unites us we can meet and master the great challenges of the day. We have the chance to draw a line under the division and distraction of the past - and to inspire the Scottish people with the kind of future we will build together.

A Scottish decade where we have good green jobs, modern manufacturing and where talent - not class - determines what happens in the classroom. A future where we see growth not just in our economy but in our ambitions - where we create a Scotland where no child is hungry, no family is cold and each generation does better than the last. That's what we're fighting for - that's what's on the ballot paper at the general election. I'd love for you to be part of it. Please get in touch and let's get started.

Owen was raised in Loanhead after moving there aged 7 when his dad became minister at Loanhead Parish Church. After attending Beeslack High School in Penicuik, Owen studied Accounting and Finance at Napier University. After working in the financial Services industry for a period Owen was elected to Midlothian Council in November 2005 at the Loanhead by-election. At this time Owen was the youngest Councillor in Scotland.

Owen started on the campaign trail early having delivered his first leaflets aged 8. He was successfully re-elected in both 2007 and 2012 becoming Leader of Midlothian Council in 2013. 

Owen enjoys football, rugby, craft beer, and films.

Living in North Wymondham, Michael shares the concerns of local residents about the cost of living, the state of public services, local GPs and NHS provision, and the effects of climate change as flooding and wildfires are becoming more frequent. Together with the other candidates in Wymondham, if elected as Councillor, Michael will be working for the positive change that people living or working in Wymondham deserve.

Deanna has lived in Haywards Heath for the last 26 years. Previously an IT systems manager, for the last 15 years she has been teaching maths and physics at 6th form level. As a former Head of Science at Haywards Heath College before it closed, she has seen first-hand the difficulties of central government funding cuts, and the direct impact on services in the area, due to lack of strategic planning and support from current local Councils at all levels. If elected, Deanna will focus on green sustainable local projects, looking at the impact of the current house building boom, and addressing the lack of supporting infrastructure such as green transport options (buses and safe cycle routes), schools, doctor’s surgeries and leisure facilities. She will campaign to make sure property developers are held to their targets of affordable and social housing, and their promises on protection of trees and the local environment.

My life has had its share of highs and lows; in the 1980s, I was homeless and hopeless. The experience stayed with me and kept me grounded through my later success, in 2013 I qualified as a solicitor and in 2023, I headlined Wembley Stadium with Blur.



My passion is working in the community, bringing people together and solving problems. 14 years of Conservative governments have left the UK in a desperate state. Public services are barely working, and we've had a succession of Prime Ministers acting as if the rules don't apply to them.



We can do better. As part of a Labour government, I want to help rebuild Mid Sussex. Transform the NHS, revitalise public services, and create water, power and rail networks that put consumers first, not shareholders.



I can only do this with your help.

We need a Labour MP to make sure we get our fair share from the next Labour government.

The latest polling shows the Lib Dems are now a distant third place; only Labour can beat the Conservatives here. I ask that you give me a chance to show you what I can do.

party_name: Alliance - Alliance Party of Northern Ireland

statement_to_voters: Emily Darlington is Labour's Parliamentary Candidate for Milton Keynes Central. She has been delivering for MK as a councillor for many years including the biggest council house building programme for a generation, enhancing the biodiversity, striving towards a Dementia Friendly City and tackling violence towards women and girls by leading the White Ribbon City ambition. She lives in Milton Keynes with her husband and two children.

Milton Keynes is where I was born, went to school in, started my first job, and where my family still live and works today. However, in its near 60-year history, it has never had an MP who grew up here.

Instead, for the last 14 years, it has been served by Tory MPs who have let the city down and refused to fight for our local area. I will be an MP who fights for our city.

This is personal to me -- my family work in our local public services, my mum as a teacher and my brother as a firefighter. I've seen first-hand how more than a decade of Tory policy has undermined their craft and the services they provide. But in order to improve things we need a Labour government, and that won't happen unless we win in marginal seats like Milton Keynes North.

So get involved, because together we can win for Milton Keynes, and we can win for Labour.
I'm honoured to have the opportunity to represent Milton Keynes - the city I love and the city I call home.

Jenifer has been a Merton Councillor since taking the seat from Labour at the 2019 Cannon Hill by-election.  Jenifer has led calls for urgent action on the Climate Emergency demanding Merton Council divest from fossil fuels, reduce the use of single use plastic and produce a Tree and Biodiversity Strategy for Merton. An avid campaigner on local issues, Jenifer champions road safety, air quality and the environment.

The Green Party’s parliamentary candidate for Mitcham and Morden, Dr Pippa Maslin, was a state secondary school English teacher for thirteen years, and then a carer for her father and a media arts university tutor during the completion of her Ph.D. Following five years as a caseworker at a local Deaf and Disabled People’s Organisation, which involved providing information, advice and advocacy to people needing help with welfare benefits, social care, housing, and concessionary travel, she now holds the post of Policy and Campaigns Manager.

Born to a Filipina and a Briton, Pippa moved from Manila to Morden in 1977 and, after some time away, returned to the borough of Merton in 2013. Angered by pernicious ‘austerity measures’ imposed by the coalition government, she joined The People’s Assembly Against Austerity. Determined to fight cuts to essential local services, particularly in adult social care and at St Helier Hospital, she threw herself into campaigning.

In 2015, Pippa and her neighbours found themselves having to fight their housing association, Clarion, to lower a bill for major works. The ward Councillors proved ineffective. Thus, the residents took matters into their own hands and managed to negotiate about 60% off the original figure. In the same year, she joined the National Health Action Party because she felt compelled to counter unjust cuts to local healthcare and the burgeoning backdoor privatisation of our NHS.

A move to the Green Party came shortly after and, in 2017, Pippa was a candidate in a by-election for the ward in which she lives. Since then, she has represented her ward in subsequent council elections and stood as the Mitcham and Morden candidate for the General Election in 2019, as well as the London Assembly candidate for Merton and Wandsworth in 2021 and 2024.

Notably, after encountering, in late 2018, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change’s Special Report on Global Warming, the next year saw Pippa create and lead a successful petition to Merton Council to declare a climate emergency and review its current carbon reduction plans for the borough to help to limit global warming to 1.5°C - going on to work with the Council, as part of a Climate Emergency Working Group, to create a Climate Strategy and Action Plan.

More recently, Pippa has: worked with a grassroots group whose central aim is to lobby for and shape improvements in infrastructure for active travel in Merton; helped a coalition of residents’ associations and individuals opposing the All England Lawn Tennis Club’s excessive proposal to expand its site; supported residents in Mitcham to reject an inappropriate plan for the old gasworks site; and attended peace vigils and marches calling for a bilateral ceasefire and the release of all hostages in Israel and Gaza. Further to this, she belongs to Friends of Morden Recreation Ground and, after a few years of joining up with neighbours to protect Morden Park from inappropriate commercial use, now sits on the committee for Friends of Morden Park.

Outside of work and activism, Pippa loves to walk, watch birds, learn about wildlife, eat out, and listen to music.

party_name: Plaid Cymru - The Party of Wales

statement_to_voters: I believe that Monmouth deserves an MP who demonstrates compassion rather than cynicism, takes action on climate change instead of denying the clear scientific evidence, and protects our public services instead of cutting them to the bone.  I want a future where our air and water is clean and our food healthy; where our energy comes from the wind, the waves and the sun; where the young are encouraged to use their talents and fulfil their dreams; where the elderly and disabled play an active role in our communities; where diversity is valued; where the vulnerable are protected; and where everyone is supported to have good mental and physical health. Together we can help make this future happen. Vote Green.

June is a Welsh speaking mother of three from Cardigan who has settled in the Monmouthshire area since 2001.

A graduate of the University of Wales, Swansea, 1987 June holds a degree in History and English Literature. June also holds an MSc in Tourism Management from UWIC, Cardiff and a PGCE/QTS in Business Studies and Economics. June is a passionate educator who has taught in Cardiff, Monmouth and the Forest of Dean working in the secondary school sector to inspire young people to develop their passions through enterprise activities. June currently serves her local community in Redbrook as a parish councillor.

In 2019 she stood as a candidate in the Newport West by-election and European Parliament elections as a vocal proponent of the need for political reform to end corruption in politics. June is passionate about driving grassroots participation in civic life, the need to protect the environment and improving civic engagement in her community.

In her leisure time June sings with a local community choir, enjoys live music and heritage in the outdoors. The True & Fair Party was launched by Gina Miller earlier in 2022 to tackle political corruption an institutional weaknesses, and campaign for the modernisation of UK democracy.

June's top 3 local priorities are:

Save our Rivers - The fragile ecosystems of the Wye, Usk and Severn and their tributaries are in crisis as a result of the expansion of intensive farming, an inadequate regulatory framework and systemic failures of water utilities to invest in solutions to inadequate combined sewage overflows and surface water drainage.

Affordable Homes and Cost of Living Crisis Beating Local Jobs

Joined up, cross border thinking on planning and infrastructure investment is needed urgently to build sustainable, affordable housing with a well connected transport and community infrastructure that meets the needs of future generations

Economic Regeneration to Deliver Practical Support for Small Businesses

Incentives and grants to encourage new start up businesses and growing businesses. Invest in hybrid working hubs in under-used building in our four main retail centres: Abergavenny, Monmouth, Usk and Chepstow to regenerate town centres #shoplocal #visitmonmouthshire #Regenerativefarming #excluded #shoplocal Farming- Energise our beleaguered agri-tourism sector through accessible sustainable farming schemes - prioritise regenerative farming for food security #youngfarmers #landaccessnow #OneMillionAcres

I have lived in Monmouth constituency for over 20 years - both the fantastic people and the beauty of the place brought me here. It's a wonderful area to bring up my two children. I've been involved in the community ever since I moved here, most recently as a County Councillor and Cabinet Member for Equalities at Monmouthshire County Council.

As Chief Executive of a charity campaigning for a fairer Wales, I'm proud to have doubled our funding and grown our impact in recent years, winning important campaigns as well as two National awards.

Monmouth's residents are some of the kindest and fairest that I have known but they do not have a government in Westminster who treats them fairly. Monmouth needs an MP who is committed to strengthening the economy to fix the chaos caused by the Tories over the past 13 years, an MP who can make Monmouth fairer, bringing funding to the area to regenerate our high streets and invest in public services, as well as an MP who will take the climate emergency seriously.

Together, it's time to build a stronger, fairer, greener Monmouth Constituency.

I'd love to answer any questions you may have or please do get in touch to help us win Monmouth for Labour.

I am running for MP because I want to focus on one of the biggest issues in Monmouthshire, which is the cuts to important services that support vulnerable adults.

I used to work in care and ever since I found out about the council trying to sell Tudor Street Day Centre for flats, I have been campaigning to stop this happening. The building is fit for purpose with accessibility and facilities that support adults with complex needs. The campaign started in 2022 and is still ongoing.

I have worked with a team to put together a community group called The Gathering, which currently meets regularly at the Wellbeing Hub. That location, whilst good for now, is still not accessible for people with complex needs. Other services, like Budden Crescent, have been closed, and this has severely affected the service users, their families and staff. 

If elected, I will continue to fight for better services and support for vulnerable adults, and I will also push for fit-for-purposes buildings to give these vulnerable people a place to go and get better opportunities. 

In addition to disability rights, I want to bring democracy more generally back into local communities. I am tired of politics being run from the top down. I will be a true representative of what the constituents of Monmouthshire want, in all areas.

favourite_biscuit: flapjack - I use a recipe I have perfected over the years.
statement_to_voters:
I am delighted to be the candidate for the Green Party for the next general election. 

The Green Party is the only party addressing the climate emergency with the seriousness it deserves. It is the defining issue of this generation and if we do not drastically cut our carbon emissions our grandchildren will inherit a wrecked planet.

In 2015, world leaders in Paris agreed that to prevent widespread future famine, loss of life and more and dangerous extremes in weather patterns - we need to keep the mean temperature rise below 1.5°C.  However, we have already breached this target in 2023 and global carbon emissions are still rising. The effect of El Niño last year may mean a temporary dip below 1.5°C again but the trend is upwards and this illustrates how serious the situation is.

That said, the Green Party has never been just about climate change - it is also the party of social justice – the two are inextricably linked.  We need to rapidly rethink how we enable a smooth transition to a low carbon economy alongside reform of our services to create a just and fair society so I look forward to sharing our ideas on health, education, farming, housing, transport and other policy areas over the next few months.

My background is that for the last 10 years I have worked for social enterprises setting up community energy schemes and delivering domestic energy efficiency advice, but my early career was in analysis of the transmission system with National Grid.

I was fortunate to have access to a good university education, and believe that education is the key to all other aspects of a compassionate society. Without a top-class education system we will not have the engineers, doctors, nurses, and yes, wise and compassionate politicians of the next generation.

I love where I live. It’s my home. I left for university and came back because it’s such a wonderful place to live, but far too few young people have returned. They love it here, but they don’t see the opportunities for the future. Jobs are the major barrier.

I’d like to stop that ‘brain drain’, and make sure that more young, skilled people and their families feel able to stay in here.

Montgomeryshire & Glyndŵr needs an MP that they can trust, one that will represent people, of all ages and backgrounds.

 The Liberal Democrats have always stood up for rural areas like ours, when Montgomeryshire used to have a Liberal Democrat voice in Parliament, you knew you could count on them to raise the important issues.

Just over the border, we’ve seen how Liberal Democrat MP Helen Morgan has been a relentless champion for her residents on the poor situation at Shrewsbury and Telford hospitals and long ambulance waiting times, raising it constantly.

Meanwhile the Conservatives in Montgomeryshire have been totally absent and are letting our residents down. We need a voice that will call for better access to healthcare, call for action to tackle sewage dumping and climate change and who will fight for jobs and help during the cost-of-living crisis.

I also want to see more power put in the hands of local people. I believe in community - and that we can help communities do things for themselves. Decisions taken locally are usually better decisions.

party_name: Plaid Cymru - The Party of Wales

statement_to_voters:
For 14 years, almost everything in our country has gone backwards. Waiting lists are at record highs. So is the tax burden. Crime, child poverty, and homelessness are all rising. We have become less prosperous compared to other major economies. Court backlogs and a lack of investment in prisons means our justice system is on its knees. The same is true for most public services, not least our buckling National Health Service.

Five Tory prime ministers have given us austerity, a cost-of-living crisis, a stagnant economy, and international isolation. They are not a serious party of government and we cannot risk another five years of Tory chaos.

My whole life is in this constituency. I teach its amazingly bright and talented children and raise my own in Acrefair. We have so much going for us, whether it is Ruabon’s proud industrial heritage, the grandeur of Powis and Chirk castles, Machynlleth’s art, festivals, and culture, or Rhosllanerchrugog’s strong vibrant Welsh community.

This election will be the first contested under new constituency boundaries, which have completely changed the political landscape here. The Liberal Democrats may in the past have been the traditional alternative to the Tories in Montgomeryshire, but with the addition of 13 Labour-voting wards in the north of our new constituency, on top of their plummeting vote share since 2010, this is simply no longer the case – a vote for them is now a vote to let the Tories sneak back in.

Montgomeryshire & Glyndŵr deserves so much better. Tory economic incompetence has decimated public finances and our local economies. Mid Wales has lost its Air Ambulance base. Welshpool had no banking access whatsoever for a whole year. There is still no health hub in Newtown.

For a region so dependent on reliable transport links, this Tory decline has hit us particularly hard. Rural bus services have halved in the past decade and a half. For Llanidloes, the only large town in Montgomeryshire without a train station, this causes pointless delays with the bus to Caersws missing connecting trains by minutes.

I am unashamedly proud of our farmers, who do so much for our local economy. Here again, Tory incompetence has hit us where it hurts, with Boris Johnson’s disastrous trade deal with Australia selling out the farming community. His successor as prime minister, Liz Truss, said he had “conceded the whole kingdom” with the deal. We welcome the news that rural voters are increasingly considering voting Labour. We will not take your support for granted and will support Welsh farmers by reducing the reliance on imported food and by cutting red tape at the border.

Labour has brought Britain back from the brink before. We will do so again. With Labour governments in Westminster, Cardiff Bay, and with a Labour MP in Montgomeryshire & Glyndŵr, we will work together to bring about a decade of renewal.

I will be a loud voice in Westminster for properly funding public services, most importantly our NHS. I will support restrictions on shameful corporate lobbying and back Labour’s plans to abolish the House of Lords. As a trade unionist since age 19 and current executive member of my trade union, I will back public sector workers to the hilt and stand up for workers’ rights. I fully support the creation of Great British Energy and the nationalisation of our railways, which I will leverage to bring cheap, clean energy and more reliable train services into our communities. I will call for an ambitious Green New Deal and make sure we protect our party democracy. I will work with MPs of any stripe in Dwyfor Meirionnydd, Radnorshire, Wrexham, Shropshire and Ludlow to keep our communities connected and drive the growth of our local economies.

Polls are showing a very close race between Labour and the Tories. If you are a Lib Dem, Plaid, or Green voter, we need you to lend us your vote so we can send a clear message to Rishi Sunak, who’s parliamentary private secretary is our very own Tory MP Craig Williams. He and his colleagues have taken rural, traditional areas like ours for granted. 14 years later and we desperately need change. A vote for Labour is a vote for that change.

From Rhos and Ruabon to Llanfyllin and Llangurig, in Chirk, Cefn, Welshpool, Machynlleth, and everywhere inbetween, I will be an MP for all of Montgomeryshire & Glyndŵr. I will fight tirelessly to secure our place in a more prosperous, safer, and greener Wales.

I care about people, I want to enhance our lives, our homes, our high street and this planet we all live on. This means listening and acting on what can make a difference. A thriving town, well insulated homes, access to good food and a safe world to live in.

I'm not a professional politician. I'm an NHS care worker

from Kinloss. I am standing in the general election

because I believe Scotland deserves better than the two

governments -- Tory and SNP -- that have let us down so

badly.

If elected to serve as your MP, I will dedicate myself to

representing you and improving our communities to

the very best of my ability, with no other jobs and an

accessible office in the heart of our community.

With real-life experience under my belt, I understand

the challenges local families face. As a father of young

children I want to ensure that every young person can be

assured of a safe and prosperous future.

We can rebuild our local NHS, create good jobs and give

all children an education to help them succeed but it

requires commitment and focus,

Only Scottish Labour can bring the real, meaningful

change we need here in Moray West, Nairn & Strathspey.

Lizzi Collinge is the candidate for the new Morecambe and Lunesdale constituency, having been selected by local members in September 2023. Lizzi was born near Blackburn but grew up in a small village in Cumbria. She moved to the area in 2005 and now lives in Heysham with her husband and two kids.



A project manager by trade, Lizzi is an experienced representative having been elected to Lancashire County Council in 2016 where she now serves as Shadow Cabinet Member for Health and Wellbeing. Lizzi is also the Deputy Chair of Lancashire Health and Adult Services Scrutiny Committee. She is passionate about health and ensuring that health is considered in all areas of policy.



With a reputation for empathy, hard work and tenacity, Lizzi enjoys widespread support across the new constituency. After her selection Lizzi said: "I hope to win people's trust to represent them in Westminster and to help deliver the change our country so desperately needs. People are fed up of public services that are run into the ground and an economy that doesn't work for them, especially when the Government doesn't seem to care about basic decency and honesty. People have been badly let down.



"People in Morecambe and Lunesdale deserve an MP who will fight their corner and I plan to be a great constituency MP."



In her spare time Lizzi is a keen gardener, growing her own fruit and veg and making her own preserves.

Gina has held many key roles representing the Green Party during her 30 years as a member: she was formerly a Lancaster City Councilllor and is currently the sole Green County Councillor on Lancashire County Council, where her work campaigning on fracking, responsible investment by the County pension fund, and ending single-use plastics at County level has resulted in real change across Lancashire.

In the past she worked for local charities: for people with drug and alcohol issues, SCOPE, and more recently a charity in Cumbria trying to make church buildings more sustainable. Her primary career was in the NHS in public health project management. In addition to being a councillor she now works very part-time as a personal assistant for someone with disabilities.

One of her proudest achievements is playing a key part in getting Lancaster funded for massive improvements to cycling (£1.5 million); and in 2002 daring to expose the City Council's secret decision to give financial support to the nuclear industry (which resulted in her being suspended from the Council for three months although meanwhile re-elected with a bigger majority).

On Lancashire County Council she has been proud to support those fighting the shale gas industry on the Fylde - and to shine a light on the real risks that fracking brings. She does not shy away from meaningful action, and in addition to her numerous interventions and motions at full council and in the democratic process she was arrested and charged for obstruction of the highway in direct action outside the Preston New Road site in November 2017. She lives in Lancaster with her partner; her two sons have mainly left home; she likes dancing and loves cycling holidays.
I will ensure people only pay for the services they need and not forced to pay for vanity projects to satisfy a vocal minority. If we have to have a democracy, it should be a democracy.

Donald is a retired medical doctor and leader of the Scottish Christian Party, the Scottish end of the Christian Party.

He is the SCP Candidate on the Highlands and Islands Regional List for the All For Unity Party in the May 2021 Election to the Scottish Parliament.

He has composed the SCP Manifestos since 2006 and has been SCP leader since 2010.

Islanders feel they have been taken for granted for too long. Na h-Eileanan an Iar constituency has been ignored by an uncaring Tory government which fuelled the cost-of-living crisis and neglected by an SNP government whose incompetence handled us a ferry crisis, a housing crisis and the danger of depopulation.



We have come to a crossroads where we can shape our own future as a vibrant island communities, tapping into the support of a change-making Labour government, or we can slip back into further division under Tory and nationalist rule.



I grew up in Lewis and know all the islands well from my work as a newspaper reporter and programme maker for the BBC. As a journalist in Westminster for many years I have seen politics close up.



I don't need a map of the Hebrides or the House of Commons to tell me only Labour can bring about the economic and democratic renewal the country and the islands demand.



As a Labour MP I will shape policy for the islands and speak up for the islands. We face a big challenge but Na h-Eileanan an Iar has been Labour seat before and can be again. With your support we will win here, we will see a Labour government, we will raise a new voice for the islands.

Angus Brendan MacNeil was born and brought up in Tangasdale, on the Isle of Barra. He was educated at Castlebay School Isle of Barra; The Nicolson Institute, Isle of Lewis, Strathclyde University and Jordanhill, Glasgow.

After working as a journalist with the BBC, he taught for two years in Salen, Isle of Mull, where he started the Gaelic Medium Unit before moving to Fort William. Angus Brandan lives on the family croft with his wife Jane and their three daughters. He is an active crofter and enjoys fishing and football.

Angus Brendan MacNeil was elected MP for Na h-Eileanan an Iar in 2005 and he has a high profile throughout his constituency. The main islands in the constituency, which is the length of Wales, include Lewis and Harris, North Uist, Benbecula, South Uist and Barra.

Over the last Parliament Angus Brandan has successfully fought for his constituents on issues as varied as coastguards, fishing, fuel and mobile phone connectivity.

party_name: Plaid Cymru - The Party of Wales

statement_to_voters: See: https://adrianamer.co.uk/manifesto

Hello, my name is Collan Siddique and I'm a Occupational Therapist in Mental Health who lives and works in Newark on Trent, what has happened in Gaza since October has inspired me to try and make a change to this country politically. Neither of the main two political parties in this country have stood up against genocide taking place abroad in Gaza. I am the prospective parliamentary candidate for Newark for Workers Party of Britain. I have lived in Newark on Trent since 2020 and am passionate for Newark to have a working class voice in Westminster that is independent from the two big political parties - that offer no solutions to poverty, social mobility, the environment and industry.

Honesty, integrity and compassion.

These have been missing from our politics for too long. Now at long last we can try and change that.

Newark residents have a chance to reject unequivocally the politics of hate and instead to embrace the politics of hope.

Whether it is saving the NHS, protecting the environment, stopping sewage dumping or tackling the cost of living crises, we have the answers.

The Conservative Party that once existed is now gone. In its place we have an extreme right-wing party seeking to fight culture wars. Most Newark residents are appalled by this. My message to them is that when your party changes it's time to change your party.

In this election a vote for the LibDems will ensure that we can have a real local champion here.

I’m Liz Bell and I am fed up with the brutality of austerity that sees so many people in Britain relying on food-banks while the country’s billionaires get richer, with a government that seems to be doing its best to destroy the NHS, with cuts in public services, with privatisation aimed at making the rich richer and the poor poorer, with big polluters destroying our environment, and with the lies of the Tory elite who pretend it’s all in our best interests. The Conservative slogan is “Britain deserves better.” Yes, better than the nine years of Tory rule that has brought this country to its knees.

That’s why I have recently joined the Labour Party and am standing to be your MP. The country is in crisis but the good news is that it is not too late. I support Labour’s ambitious election campaign - the most ambitious and radical our country has ever seen. If you want to live in a society that works for everybody and not just the billionaires, this election is your chance to vote for it.

We, the Labour Party, put our faith in the British people’s spirit and commitment to community. Wealth and power should not be in the hands of the many Boris Johnson’s Conservatives, who think they’re born to rule. They’ve slashed taxes for the richest and slashed vital services and support for everyone else. 

This election is a once-in-a generation chance to take on the vested interests holding people back and to transform our country, making sure that no community is left behind. To do this we are making these pledges: •	A properly-funded and resourced National Health Service we can all be proud of •	A social care system that gives our older people both dignity and free personal care •	A real living wage of at least £10 an hour, from the age of 16 •	Secure homes that families can afford •	Thirty hours’ free childcare for all two to four-year olds •	A good education as a right, not a privilege – and with no tuition fees - where children with special educational needs get the free education they deserve •	Efficient and affordable rail, mail and water services, owned by the public rather than the rich making themselves richer •	A chance for all voters to have a final say on Brexit because in a democracy it’s OK to change your mind •	An end to Tory austerity and Universal Credit •	An end to tax havens, dodgy landlords and bad bosses •	Real action on the climate emergency, with a Green Industrial Revolution at the heart of Labour’s plan to transform Britain

And when Labour wins, the nurse wins, the doctor wins, the pensioner wins, the student wins, the office worker wins, the engineer wins, the child wins. We all win.

Lee has lived in West Berkshire all his life. 'My wife and I both work in the local area, and our children go to local schools. We access the same services, local doctors, schools and public transport as you, and like you, we demand better from our government on the issues we all face locally and nationally. I want to see a West Berkshire that is confident for a brighter future, which is why I invite you to join me in demanding better.'

Lee became politically motivated to join the local Liberal Democrats in 1999 at the age of 16 when David Rendel was MP for Newbury. Personally seeing the positive differences that were made to the local community, Lee was inspired to become a councillor in Thatcham in 2007. Since then, he has been Mayor twice, Leader of Thatcham Town Council, and is currently the Leader of the Opposition on West Berkshire Council fighting for a better deal from central government to help fund our vital local services.

With a proven track record of standing up for residents, Lee continues to hold the Tories to account. ‘Our District has missed out on much need affordable housing and we have unnecessarily lost many community assets including Newbury football Club. We have also seen hundreds of thousands of pounds of taxpayers money being wasted defending incompetent decisions in court.’

With continued and significant electoral success for West Berkshire and Newbury Liberal Democrats, Lee and the Liberal Democrats are standing up for voters on important areas such as housing, education and the environment. Under Lee’s leadership they won widespread support from the people of West Berkshire, increasing their representation on West Berkshire Council almost fourfold and regained control of both Newbury and Thatcham town councils. 

Lee is committed to the community and people of West Berkshire and continues to stand up for our area. Your support can make the difference in giving West Berkshire a hardworking, committed local MP that will work for you.

Lee Dillon - a better future for West Berkshire.

Laura Farris is a leading barrister who specialises in employment and public law.  She is a Board Member and Trustee of an educational Academy Trust with schools in London and Berkshire. She is a former Parliamentary Candidate and has previously advised senior members of the Cabinet.

favourite_biscuit: Not allowed due to recent diagnosis of diabetes
statement_to_voters: I have lived in West Thatcham for many years. I am a passionate individual and enjoy any challenge that I am given. Residents may remember that, with the support of the local community, I was able to change a brown field site at Pound Lane into a wonderful flower meadow for children and adults to enjoy. In 2011 the West ward elected me to the Thatcham Town Council. Three years later I was honoured to accept the role of Thatcham Town Mayor. I instigated the idea of having an apple orchard situated at the Thatcham lakes. I wanted our children to play a part in their community so it was my idea as Mayor to create the Mayors Community medal. Over two hundred children took part in the challenge to absorb knowledge of our community. As a thank you to those leaders that ran various charities in West Berkshire I decided to hold a ABBA night in the St Mary’s church. The vicar mentioned the church had never rocked as much as it did that night.  I care very much about our local community, housing, adult social services. I am a solid Brexiteer and want to see our nation free of the European Union. I will work tirelessly for my community in West Thatcham.

I have lived in West Berkshire for 14 years. I am chair of trustees for Eight Bells for Mental Health Newbury, and the Green Party’s prospective parliamentary candidate for Newbury.

Having experienced homelessness personally, I co-wrote last year’s report on rough sleeping in West Berkshire, and helped to open the night shelter for homeless people because existing provision was clearly inadequate.

I served in the Royal Air Force for nearly 20 years, and have been subsequently employed as a care worker. I have three sons and two grandsons. I am a keen cyclist, and cycled across the Pyrenees last summer to raise money for Eight Bells for Mental Health.

I launched the petition calling on West Berkshire to follow the lead of other councils, declare a climate emergency, and produce a strategy to become carbon neutral by 2030. As a result, West Berkshire is obliged to hold a debate on the subject after the new council takes office in May.

post_label: Newcastle upon Tyne Central and West
Newcastle upon Tyne Central and West
statement_to_voters:
I am seeking re-election for Newcastle Central. I was born in Wallsend, grew up in North Kenton and live in Newcastle Central. I have been immensely proud to represent my city and to stand up in Parliament for the interests of the people I grew up with. Helping my constituents has been my primary aim and each month I publish on my website summaries of the casework I and my team have dealt with (www.chionwurahmp.com) I am particularly proud of the work I did to keep the Richardson Unit open at the RVI, and also campaigning against Wonga sponsoring Newcastle United, part of a process that led to

these companies being properly regulated.

As a Chartered Engineer, I am passionate about the difference technology can make to people's lives -- with the right Government! As Shadow Minister for Industrial Strategy, Science and Innovation I have worked with colleagues to develop policies for a Green Industrial Revolution, which will bring thousands of jobs to Newcastle and the North East building on our proud tradition of manufacturing.

I want to continue this work, and move the centre of gravity of our industry and prosperity Northwards. We need to resolve this Brexit crisis, but for the country not for the rich, with people having the final say. We need a Green Industrial Revolution, to rebuild the country after a decade of austerity, and to protect our vital public services.

post_label: Newcastle upon Tyne Central and West
Newcastle upon Tyne Central and West
Newcastle upon Tyne East and Wallsend
Newcastle upon Tyne East and Wallsend
Newcastle upon Tyne East and Wallsend
Newcastle upon Tyne East and Wallsend
Newcastle upon Tyne East and Wallsend
Newcastle upon Tyne East and Wallsend
statement_to_voters:
It has never been more important to have Green voices in our communities and across the country. We need common-sense, practical solutions to the biggest challenges of our time.

As a mental health worker in a Walker-based GP practice, I see the impact of 14 years of austerity every day. I see people with mental health difficulties sat on waiting lists, unable to get the support they need. I see the stress of low wages and rising rents driving people to despair, alongside NHS staff burnt out trying to meet the needs of patients. I also see community services doing their best to provide support despite never-ending funding cuts. It is clear to me the growing mental health crisis is inextricably linked to an economy that serves the very few at the expense of the many.

Despite these challenges, we have so much to be proud of in Newcastle East and Wallsend. We have a rich industrial heritage, a long history of solidarity and our famous warmth and good humour. I’m always struck by the resilience of the people I work with and I believe that given the opportunity, our communities can thrive. 

The Green Party vows to empower communities and fix the climate crisis alongside the growing crisis of inequality. We will invest in renewable energy to improve energy security and reduce both energy bills and emissions. We will build thousands of affordable houses and insulate existing ones, to make sure that everyone can live in a safe, warm home. We will provide affordable public transport to help people stay connected, improve air quality, and leave more money in your pocket. We will bring vital services like water back into public hands to protect our shared environment. The Green Party will always place people before profit.

Vote Green for “Real Hope. Real Change"

Anna Collar is currently Associate Professor of Roman Archaeology at the University of Southampton, where she is a member of the Sustainability and Biodiversity Implementation Groups.

She has previously stood for election  to the New Forest District Council, and since 2018 has volunteered as an Assistant Leader for the 1st Burley Beaver Scouts. Anna lived in Burley until 2023, where two of her children are still at school. She now lives in Lyndhurst. 

She says, “it is clear to everyone that `politics as usual’ hasn’t worked. We need a new approach. That’s why support for the Green Party has grown so rapidly. We’ve seen a surge in Green Party politicians elected. The number of green districts councillors has more than quadrupled in the last four years and increased by an impressive 200 at the local elections in May 2023. We are especially proud that, for the first time, we now have three representatives on New Forest District council. We know that we can see even better results at next general election.”

I’m a life-long local resident and councillor who has a record of getting things done in our area.

It’s clear that our area gets a raw deal from the Council. We only need to look at the state of our roads to see that.

My priorities as your Councillor will be to get things done. On roads, I will make it my priority to change the way Road resurfacing and pothole repairs are carried out so that thought is given to the smaller roads, such as Pound Road and Lower Pennington Lane, which are in terrible shape but often seen as not important enough to require fixing. 

On the environment, I will push rigorously for the Council to take more ambitious action on climate change, just as I do on Lymington and Pennington Town Council.

I will also fight for investment in our high street and village centre. We need to make Lymington and Pennington a more attractive place to live, work, and shop.

On Thursday 4th May, vote for local champions who get things done. Vote Jack Davies, Colm McCarthy and the Liberal Democrats.

The New Forest has been my home for over 35 years, and I love it. As a GP in Lymington for all those years as well as holding many clinical public service roles, I have frontline experience of what needs to change and improve in our local system. I am passionate about finding sustainable solutions to enable the NHS to deliver quality care for all.



I am committed to addressing social and health inequalities; we have areas of deep deprivation in this constituency, sadly the issues of the vulnerable are often less well addressed in areas of affluence.



If I win your vote and become elected as your MP, I will:



Address the issue of lack of affordable housing in the New Forest

Be focussed on rebuilding our public services based on sound economic foundations

Be invested in minimising the effects of climate change and in protecting the environment

Help the young and vulnerable avoid falling into illegal activities including County Lines

Push for robust mental health support across the New Forest, currently tragically under resourced

Work hard on providing more accessible help to victims of domestic violence and abusive relationships



As your MP I will be approachable and commit to working hard to ensure we have a caring, inclusive and flourishing constituency.

“Newport doesn’t need the corrupted old politics of yesterday. I’m standing for clean modern energy owned by the people, a publicly owned transport system and free university education. I’m against ideological austerity and for investment in an economy fit for the future. I firmly believe that there are not enough MP’s prepared to stand up and challenge the status quo of an eternal boom and bust economy, dirty energy and bad education. As the MP for Newport East I will be an outspoken advocate for the change to a modern, clean, healthy, economy which works for everyone, and especially the people of Newport.”

Pippa Bartolotti is also a long term campaigner for human rights and in particular works to highlight the oppression of Palestinian people. She has driven in a convoy of humanitarian aid to Gaza.

" I am horrified that both our government and the so-called opposition have cowed down under the Zionist yoke and lifted not one finger to stop the mass slaughter of Palestinians. If the British government cannot adhere to the basic tenets of International Law we cannot trust them to adhere to any other law. The rot has set into British politics, and it has to be stopped. This is why I am standing, and this is why I have chosen to stand as an Independent candidate.

party_name: Plaid Cymru - The Party of Wales
Plaid Cymru - The Party of Wales

statement_to_voters: I was born and brought up in Newport West, it is the place I still call home. I will continue to work with local people to put our city first, standing up for Newport West in Westminster.

party_name: Alliance - Alliance Party of Northern Ireland

statement_to_voters:
As a young person that lives in Kingsteignton, I see first-hand every day the damage that 14 years of Tory chaos has done to communities across our constituency. Rishi Sunak's out of touch Conservative government has crashed the economy, trashed Britain's public services and burdened hardworking families in Newton Abbot with the highest taxes since the second world war.



The promise of a Labour government has never been cause for greater optimism for families across Newton Abbot. Keir Starmer's pledge to build 1.5 million new homes, establish GB Energy to make Britain a clean energy superpower, create a new publicly owned railway company Great British Rail, offer 2 million more NHS appointments per year to clear the backlog offers the people of Newton Abbot a stark alternative to the chaos and mismanagement of the last 14 years.



As someone who works locally in hospitality, I am passionate about Labour's vision for the future of work where working people enjoy dignity, gain security, receive respect, and are supported to prosper. The Labour Party has a long and proud history of being the Party not just of working people but for working people. From day one, a Labour government will strengthen workers' rights and make Britain work for working for people in Newton Abbot. Our country remains riven by inequalities which Labour is focused on fixing -- to ensure the working people who create our nation's wealth get their fair share of it.



I'm standing to give Newton Abbot the fresh start it so desperately needs. It's time for change in South Devon and I am determined to fight tooth and nail and give everything I have to represent the people of Newton Abbot as the town's MP and provide the effective local representation we so desperately need.

Anne Marie Morris was elected the Member of Parliament for Newton Abbot in 2010 and was re-elected in May 2015 with an increased majority of 11,235, a majority of 23.4%. Anne Marie lives in Newton Abbot and has a family history in Devon that can be traced back some 200 years, she also likes to get out and about in the community with her two dogs (Perdie and Darcy). Anne Marie holds regular surgeries across the constituency and also meets constituents in Westminster. See the ‘Events’ page for more information on where your local surgeries are and how to book an appointment.

Anne Marie dedicates much of her time in Westminster to issues relating to health and social care, business issues and the UK’s future outside of the European Union. She has set up two new APPG’s since her re-election and is the current Chairperson of both groups. The first is on Rural Health and Social Care, inspired by the problems faced in the health and care sector in the South West because of the regions rurality. The second, is on Business Brexit, considering how businesses can overcome the challenges and make the most of the opportunities presented by Brexit.

Anne Marie has also joined the Public Accounts Committee, a committee that oversees and analyses government expenditure to ensure that money is well spent. She regularly leads on matters regarding health expenditure.

From 2015 – 2016, following the General Election, Anne Marie was appointed Parliamentary Private Secretary (PPS) to Nick Boles MP and Jo Johnson MP. The primary purpose of a PPS is to facilitate communication between backbench MPs and the relevant their relevant government ministers. This may involve attending meetings on their behalf when time does not allow, supporting the minister in parliamentary debates or supporting their work on legislation. Given Anne Marie’s history championing businesses, skills, universities and schools during the last parliament, this was a great opportunity to further increase her participation in the wider government policies.

Pre 2015, Anne Marie held a number of other positions. Anne Marie was elected a member of the Work and Pensions Selection Committee in October 2012 until March 2015. She also set up and chaired the All Party Parliamentary Group (APPG) for Micro Businesses in 2011, was also Chair of the APPG for Small Business and Vice Chair of the APPG for Entrepreneurship. Anne Marie was also made Conservative Small Business Ambassador for the South West by the Prime Minister.

Anne Marie continues to champion local issues by understanding the issues on the ground and representing them in Westminster. She continues to champion fairer schools funding, planning issues, flooding, broadband infrastructure and transport infrastructure.

Before becoming a member of parliament in 2010 Anne Marie ran her own micro business specialising in mentoring businesses in the South West. After a career working as a corporate lawyer and subsequently a marketing director for PriceWaterhouseCooper (PwC) and Ernst and Young. She also served as a County Councillor having been elected to the West Sussex County Council where she was Chair of the Health Overview and Scrutiny Committee.

Martin Wrigley says: “I’m driven to stand for our community, the environment, education and opportunity for all.  With our best ever local and Euro election results and membership at an all-time high there’s never been a better time to join the Liberal Democrats in our campaign for a free, fair and liberal UK. “
Martin Wrigley has been working to tackle single use plastic in our communities, and was a sponsor of the Teignbridge declaration of a climate emergency. Teignbridge are currently building a plan to increase renewable energy generation, reduce energy usage and to plant 1000 trees a year.
Martin Wrigley says: “Nationally, we have to invest in green technology and encourage new solutions to de-carbonise our industry, travel and power generation – making Britain once again a world-leader in renewable energy.
“Our planet is at breaking point. We don’t have the luxury of waiting another decade for politicians in our country to act.”

I am a good listener and I do hear. It is because of this I have been involved in the campaign to keep the library in Crown Street and I also launched the campaign to get a bus station in Darlington.  I am also aware of the Hospital campaign and have contributed by giving reasonable and valid reasons for why Darlington Memorial needs to keep its A&E and become leading providers Maternity and Pediatric services.

I am here to fight for the people of Darlington

I'm proud to be running to represent our community as a Labour Member of Parliament. The newly created Newton Aycliffe and Spennymoor constituency is my home. I was born, raised and live in Aycliffe, Mam trained at Aycliffe Hospital, Dad went to school in Ferryhill and my Grandad grew up in Trimdon.



I've dedicated my career to making a difference and have a track record of making things happen. I have professional experience of managing large teams and budgets as a housing association director, helping to build genuinely affordable homes. As a senior leader in a large local authority, I delivered major regeneration projects which brought jobs, homes and community facilities.



It would be a huge honour to be able to use my skills and experience to be the powerful voice our area deserves in Westminster.

I am a General Practitioner in Barton upon Humber and the Medical advisor to the East Riding of Yorkshire Clinical Commissioning Group. I will be campaigning and making the case that anyone who wants to properly oppose a disastrous hard Brexit, protect the NHS, and who wants Great Britain to remain open, tolerant and united, the only party to vote for is the Liberal Democrats.
The voters have a clear choice both here in Morley and Outwood and Nationally; vote conservative for a hard Brexit and penny pinching cuts to public services; vote Labour for uncertainty and a long unaffordable wish list; or vote Liberal Democrat for a sensible middle ground approach both to the economy and to future relations with Europe and the rest of the world.

What one thing do you think Wakefield District Council has to change it’s approach towards? Climate change! Of course, very on brand for us Greens. Public transport is a big issue in the area, especially out in Featherstone. There are train and bus services, but trains can be infrequent and are expensive! Some subsidised travel on public transport and better provisions for active transport (footpaths, protected cycle lanes etc) would help reduce personal vehicle use in the area, decreasing traffic and increasing air quality. What difference do you think a Green Party Councillor could make in Featherstone? I think that it’s important that Labour are held to account in Featherstone. Labour councillors are constantly elected in Featherstone without too much contest from other parties. A Green councillor in the ward would put pressure on Labour to be active in their area and work hard for the people they represent. What five words (or phrases) best describe you as a prospective councillor? Hard working, dedicated, trustworthy, focused and willing to stand up for issues that voters are facing! How would a Green approach help ordinary people to better manage the cost of living? 1. Retrofitting. Rolling out insulation in all existing properties to ensure that heating bills are as low as possible by ensuring the heat stays in! 2. Investment in renewable energy. No more oil and gas power stations, with massive emissions and unsightly cooling towers, and instead moving to solar and wind power, which is the cheapest (and of course cleanest!) source of energy. 3. Implementing a Universal Basic Income. Replacing the current Universal Credit system which is not fit for purpose with a new UBI system, guaranteeing a decent basic income for everyone. All 3 of these need implementing together to help the cost of living crisis.
Aloha, I would like to do politics differently as our communities can grow and develop - I'd love to represent our constituency in Parliament and let them know straight up what's going on :)

Chris has always had a strong sense of right and wrong, with an emphasis on fairness above all. He has also always held liberal philosophies such as the right to live your life without fear or prejudice whilst also respecting the principles of avoiding or minimising harm to others caused by your or someone else’s actions. As he grew up his ideas evolved and matured, as they do for everyone, through the benefits of lived experience and the challenges that life always throws at you. Chris was brought up in a safe and secure environment and spent much of his youth as part of the Red Cross supporting many areas of the community. He was educated at the Royal Grammar School in High Wycombe where he was lucky to visit Germany, France and Russia and had the harrowing experience of seeing the Berlin Wall before its fall. He decided to leave home at 18 and sought to build a new life with his then fiancée, Justine. They moved several times during their lives, living and working in many parts of the UK including London, Kent, Buckinghamshire, Clackmannanshire, Livingston and, most recently, Northamptonshire where they decided to finally settle and start a family. Their son, Michael, was born after they were married for nearly 20 years and he is now studying at the University of Northampton. Chris has also worked in many other countries including France, Spain, India, Fiji, Mauritius, the Middle East and the United States as part of roles based in the UK. These experiences helped to round out his understanding of many parts of the UK and the wider world and their cultures.

His father was based on a Minesweeper during the second half of the Second World War and helped fight to preserve our democratic freedoms from the oppression of the extreme right wing and fascism. In recent years these have been under attack from within, with many tactics used in autocratic states seeding their way into life in the UK. This, along with the antiquated First Past the Post electoral system has put our basic human rights and freedoms under attack, invisible to many, like the frog in the boiling pot. Chris decided that enough was enough, he could no longer leave protecting our health, security and inalienable freedoms to the Conservatives, and does not trust Labour to be brave enough to lead us back to our basic British ideals of fairness, care and inclusivity, preferring achieving and staying in power rather than persuade the great British public to support what will, in fact rather than ideology, make us all better off financially and culturally.

Lucy grew up near Northampton and she is Labour's parliamentary candidate for Northampton North. Lucy is determined to secure a Labour Government that delivers jobs, investment and the quality public services that the town deserves, and that Britain so desperately needs.

Lucy is a competition lawyer and a partner in London firm Hausfeld & Co LLP. She has previously worked for Slaughter and May, the Office of Fair Trading, Which? and the United Nations Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia. Lucy is listed in the Legal 500 as ""an outstanding junior partner"" and regularly speaks at conferences regarding competition law and collective redress. Lucy is passionate about access to justice and she has been involved in the development of a number of law centres. She currently serves on the board of the Collective Redress Lawyers Association.

At long last this inept Conservative Government is doing what the public has been begging them to do for months and months – it is standing down. They have failed to fulfil the promises that they made in 2019. They have let down ordinary working families, and everyone you ask says it’s time for a change. The outgoing Government has failed to deal with the problems in the NHS, they have failed to deal with the cost of living crisis, and they have allowed the water companies to give their executives massive bonuses while they pump raw sewage into our waterways. Your Conservative MP voted against a recent amendment that would have made those bosses criminally liable. It really is time for a change.

Every vote for the Liberal Democrats is a vote for a fair deal. It’s a vote for a party that will stand up for our community and our health services.

Mike Reader is your parliamentary candidate for the next general election. Mike has a vision for Northampton - to make it greener, more prosperous and fairer. Mike brings over fifteen years of experience working in the construction industry to bear as your parliamentary candidate, skilled in bringing different parties together to solve seemingly impossible problems, creating new jobs and business opportunities for small and medium sized businesses. He currently leads a team at an international consultancy and construction firm who design and implement campaigns to help governments achieve best value from their construction and infrastructure projects across the globe, from new railways in Canada to schools in Australia, to regeneration programmes in Greece.

Mike is internationally recognised as a leader in his field, having been named UK Young Achiever of the Year by Constructing Excellence in 2016 and a Global 40 under 40 leader by the APMP in 2020, as well as receiving the International Award for Excellence in 2022 from industry peers.

As a passionate campaigner and environmentalist, Mike is determined to bring new green jobs to Northampton, clean up our streets and solve the air pollution crisis in the town.

Mike lives in Northampton, and as a local resident, is an active member of our community, already helping to make the town better.
